Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I have completed this book for you, O Sons, which is the last one in the science of medicine along with its complement, and after I have reached the end in it through its expositions and declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this Treatise which is a part of operation, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since operation with the hand is prostrate in our region and at our time completely, until perhaps it has perished, and its trace has vanished; and only small descriptions of it remain in the books of the ancients, which have been corrupted by hands; and error and hesitation occurred to them until their intentions were closed, and the force was elongated; It seemed to me that I should bring it to life with the arrangement of this Treatise according to its position, declaration, and abbreviation; and to come with the shapes of the tools of the Cautery, and the remaining instruments of work; which is made by addition from the declarations, and by the properation of what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why a good craftsman of this art with his hand is not found in our time is because the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained before that in the science of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the help for the members, and their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, and their number, and their exit, and the pulses of veins and arteries, and their quiets, and their locations.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And for this reason Hippocrates said that much is the name with the name, and little is the work, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 We have already spoken about it at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 Since one who does not know what we have said about anatomy will fall into error and kill men, as I have seen many of those who are formed in this science and boast of it without knowledge and without experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 Because I saw a foolish doctor cut off a scrofulous apostema on a woman's neck and cut some arteries in the neck; therefore, the woman bled to death until she fell dead in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 And I saw another doctor who presumed to remove a stone from an old man who had passed his prime, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 Therefore he came to him and removed it with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 Wherefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 And indeed I had already been summoned to remove it; and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 And I saw another doctor who was receiving a stipend from one of our land's dukes because of medicine; and a black eunuch was with him, who sustained a fracture near his heel; and the doctor, with his ignorance, bound up the fracture over an ulcer with pulley irons and tightened it strongly, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 Then he cured him according to his devices.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 Afterwards he dismissed him for some days and ordered him not to loosen the bandage; and he stood thus until the apostema grew on his leg, and his foot, and came to destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 Therefore I was summoned to him; and I hastened to loosen the bandage; and peace came upon him, and he was released from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 The corruption had already been confirmed in the member; and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Then, the corruption ceased to walk around in the member, until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 And I saw another physician who pierced a cancerous boil; and it ulcerated for days, until the wickedness of it with its lord was manifested.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 This is because when it is a pure cancer from black bile, then it is not fitting to reach it with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can bear it, so that the whole of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And for that reason, according to O Filii, it is necessary for you to know that an operation is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation which is associated with safety; and the operation with which there is danger in many arrangements.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already awakened in every place of this book where the operation comes that has fear and terror.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore, it is necessary for you to be careful of that and divide it yourself so that fools do not find a way to talk and disgrace.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Therefore, take the measure with care and protection, and take care of your weak ones with ease and firmness, and use a better way leading by God's grace to health and praiseworthy success; and let go of fearsome illnesses difficult to cure; and remove yourselves from that which makes you afraid, so that hesitation in faith and your comfort may not enter upon you.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it remains more for your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 Galenus has already said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat evil sickness; do not be called a bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now, however, I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters. ¶
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On cautery with fire and cautery with sharp medicine, this chapter is arranged, from the head to the feet, and on the shapes of instruments and tools for cauterization, as well as everything that is necessary during the procedure. [Paragraph break]
Capitulum secundum.	 De incisionibus generaliter: et de incisione capitae, et
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 Chapter Two. [Paragraph break] On general incisions and the incision of the head, [paragraph break] On section and perforation, phlebotomy and ventosities, and wounds; as well as extraction of arrows and similar objects: and all arranged in the shapes of instruments. [Paragraph break]
Capitulum tertium.	 De cauterio cum igne et Cauterio cum medicina acuta,
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 Chapter Three. [Paragraph break] On cautery with fire and cautery with sharp medicine, [paragraph break] On restoration, dislocation, treatment of twisting, and similar cases: arranged from the head to the feet, and on the shapes of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Surgical Book of Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 [Paragraph break] On the benefit and harm of cautery; when it is suitable, and at what time; whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	 Chapter One. [Paragraph break] De Iuuamento
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 Before I remember the procedure with it, however, it is necessary to say the quality of its benefits and harms, and in what constitution it should be used. [Paragraph break] Chapter One. [Paragraph break] On the benefit.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 I therefore say that the discourse on the quality of the benefit and harm of cautery is a long, subtle, scientific, and hidden knowledge. [Paragraph break] Chapter One. [Paragraph break] On the benefit.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 And there was much wisdom spoken about it and they disagreed on it; and for me, enough from their words is sufficient, fearing prolongation. [Paragraph break] Chapter One. [Paragraph break] On the benefit.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 I therefore say that cautery applies universally to all constitutions, whether with matter or without; except for two constitutions, which are a hot constitution without matter, and a dry constitution without matter. [Paragraph break] Chapter One. [Paragraph break] On the benefit.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 In a hot and dry composition, they separated from the matter.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 Some say that Cautery is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others say the opposite, that Cautery is not appropriate in a disease which is due to heat and dryness, because the nature of fire is heat; it is inappropriate to cure a hot and dry disease with heat and dryness.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he who says the opposite said that Cautery is beneficial for every hot and dry disease which occurs in human bodies, because when you compare a human body and its humors, according to the constitution of fire, you find a cold body in humans.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I myself say through his speech, because I have already seen that many times confirmed to me.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 Nevertheless, it is not necessary for him to come upon it unless he who has already been tested and trained in the last chapter on Cautery, and knows the diversity of human constitutions, the disposition of diseases in themselves, their causes, their qualities, their accidents, and the duration of the diseases.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 Concerning the other constitutions, there is no fear for you: and especially for cold and moist diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 Indeed, all physicians agree on these: and they have not separated from the benefit when using Cautery for them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, my children, that from the secret of curing by Cautery with fire, and the goodness of it over Cautery with medicine burning, is that fire is simple, whose action does not reach except to the member being cauterized; and it does not harm another part joined with it unless it causes a slight damage.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of medicine burning reaches to that which is extended from the limbs; and perhaps it causes a difficult-to-heal disease in the member, and perhaps it kills it.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 Fire, on account of its subtlety and goodness of substance, does not do that except when it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 We have now come to know that (something), through experience, because of the length of service and study with art, and due to its conformity to truth: and because of this I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not forbidden to this book of mine, I would bring you the secret hidden in fire and the quality of its operation in expelling bodies, which expels diseases with a philosophical explanation demonstrated, which could be understood by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, sons, that they themselves differ in the time when cautery is to be done, and they put a better time for it according to truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that cautery is suitable at any time: therefore, because the damage caused by time is submerged in the benefit which is attracted by the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if cautery is for pain due to necessary pains, strong, sharp ones that do not tolerate delay: therefore because it is feared that from them there might occur a greater mischief than the small damage caused by time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	 And let not that enter your minds, sons, that it is not thought except by the common people and foolish doctors, namely that to the ailment which is cured by cautery there is no return: and they put this as a consequence, and things are not so as they think: therefore because cautery is not unless in place of medicine, which alters the complexion, and extracts humidities which are the cause, that why pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 However, cautery is superfluous over medicine because of the rapidity of its health and virtue of operation and the force of its dominion: and it is possible that the ailment returns an hour of time according to the complexion of the sick person, the location of the ailment, and the power of the ailment: and what is prepared in his body from accumulation of superfluities in it: and what comes upon him in acquisition of his body from foods and similar things from causes, unless an ailment occurs, for which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 Subtle ailment in a member of few superfluities and moistures, like the cautery of a tooth, due to pain, and similar to it, is possibly such that the pain does not return in it.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 But this happens in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 However, the common saying that cautery is the last remedy of medicine is correct only to what they intend by it, because they believe that there is no healing brought about with medication nor with anything else after the fall of the cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 But this is contrary to their intention, and the saying that cautery is the last remedy of medicine is not true, unless when we administer ways of healing for some ailments, these medications do not help; then we administer cautery at the end, and it helps; thus it comes about that cautery is the last of medicines, not in accordance with the understanding of the common people and most foolish doctors.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron; and they did not say this unless for the equality of gold, and the subtlety of its substance; and they said that it does not make a wound in the place of cauterizing.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 This is not absolutely true; for I have proven this and found that it does not do this in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 And cautery with itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 But when you heat the cautery with fire from gold, it is not shown to you when heated according to the amount that you wish, due to the redness of gold; and when it goes towards it, coldness comes about, and if you add more heating on top of this, it liquefies in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 Therefore, the craftsman falls into this mistake; and for this reason we use cautery with iron more quickly and closely among us in accordance with correctness for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 And I myself have already arranged this Chapter on cautery, according to the Chapters: and I have arranged it from head to feet: so that one may alleviate what the inquirer wants from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 On the method of cauterizing the Head at the Coronal Suture.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 The cauterization here is applied to the dominion of moisture and coldness on the brain: which are two causes of scurvy, and of the flux of humors from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and of sleepiness, and toothache, and throat pain: and universally of all illness that comes from coldness, such as paralysis, scurvy, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar ones caused by these illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is that you order the sick person to: evacuate his head first with a solution of medicine cleansing it for three or four nights, according to the strength of the patient and his age and habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then order him to make his head with a linen cloth.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then make him sit between your hands square, so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Whenever therefore your middle finger comes to a place, mark that place with unburnt (material).
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then oil the Cautery Iron; of which this is its form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then place it on the marked unburnt place with a downward pressure, by which your hand is gradually tightened and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Then quickly lift your hand and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that a piece of bone or quantity of flesh has been burnt off the skull or forehead, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, repeat your hand with the iron itself, or with another one if it becomes cold: until the bones that I told you appear.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take something from salt, and dissolve it in water, and immerse the dressing in it, and place it over the location: and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place the dressing soaked in butter over it, and leave it until the burn is destroyed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with a four-ingredient ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 They have said that the more an ulcer remains open, the more pus it discharges; wherefore it is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 And some of them said that the skin should be cauterized up to the bone; and the cautery should be held until something is burned through the thickness of the bone.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then file off what has been burned from the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 And others say that when the cautery reaches the bone, it should leave an impression on it for as long as the bone falls out like the shape of a scab: or an instrument that women use to apply to the small alphabet letter: and they believe that steam from the head will escape from this place, and the wound should be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then treat it until it becomes firm.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 But these two types of cautery do not seem to me at all useful except in some people, according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And leave it alone, in my opinion, it is better for his health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 The head is weakened by the solution of its own natural continuity; as we have testified in other members; and especially when the head is naturally weak and frail; and the first type of cautery is safer and better in my opinion, and I use it: so operate with it for the benefit.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 On the method of cauterizing the head in pain of the entire head.
Caput III.	 Caput III. Inhibetur ut perforatio
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 Chapter III. It is forbidden to perform perforation when there is chronic pain in the whole head and it persists in sickness, and uses herbs, oils, and plasters.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And especially if it has already been cauterized with one cautery as we have said, and none of those [remedies] help him, then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 If the head of the sick person is strong by nature and not weak, and it finds very cold: then cauterize with another cautery under it scarcely.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize it on all its horns of the head with a cautery, so that the skin is not penetrated, and a quantity of bone is excavated as we have said.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 And cauterize it with one cautery on the back of the head at the place called vase; it is a place where a vent is placed; pour your oil into this and do not excavate the bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 The sick person finds it because of that very violent pain, and it is different from the pain of all other cauteries on the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 I will say that this cautery is in its place; it must be a cautery used for the horns of the head and the back of the head more finely with a cautery used for the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 On the method of cauterizing for hemicrania, both with burnt medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When there is pain and swelling in the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and the head is evacuated with cleansing medicines, and further treatment is administered as I have said in the divisions of diseases, but it does not improve fully: then cauterization in this case is according to two methods: either cauterization with a burning acute medicine, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 The cauterization with a burning acute medicine is: take one alum, peel it and cut off the ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then, make an incision in the time of pain with a broad lancet at the place of pain until there is a cavity under the skin where the tooth can be captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Insert it then into the cavity under the skin and let it be covered; then apply a suitable amount of pressure on top of it with a plaster and leave it for fifteen hours, then dissolve it and extract the alum, and leave the wound for two or three days: afterwards, place over it a hot compress submerged in butter until the place becomes pus-filled; then treat it with an ointment until it heals.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to do this with some burning medicines, which I have written about in the twelfth treatise, on remedies for wounds.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 Cauterization with iron is as follows:
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 Hot Iron Cautery, whose shape is as follows.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 And it is called Clauilis: because its head's shape is like a nail, in which there is something hollow, and in the middle of it there is a small projection.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the location, and hold your hand; and you turn the iron slowly with swiftness; and let the quantity that is to be burnt be equal to its thickness.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And lift your hand so that the artery, which is below, is not burnt, and let there be a flow of blood.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then immerse the cotton in salt water, and place it on the location, and leave it for three days; then immerse the cotton with butter; afterwards take care with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this hemicania with the tip of the second type of Cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 Be careful not to cut the artery in this hemicania, except for an old one specifically.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 [Title] On the method of cauterization in old hemicania.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When curing a hemicania, if the treatment mentioned from the previous cure and what was said in the division of diseases does not help: and you see from the illness that what we said with the first cautery or with cautery and fire is insufficient, then it is necessary to use cauterium ignis cultellare until it becomes white after marking the location of pain with a line, whose length is half a digit, or approximately so: and place your hand instead of one, and tighten it until you cut the artery, and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 It is necessary that you beware of the hinge part of the jaw, which moves during chewing, so as not to burn the side or the nerve that moves it, thus causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And beware of the flow of blood from the artery which was cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 Indeed, the fear is in its cutting and especially to him who does not know what he does, and is not diligent, nor experienced; and he dismisses the operation first with it.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 I will come again with a reminder of the management of bleeding from the cut artery according to its manner, and in the place of this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 If you see from the illness that this cautery is insufficient and you see the weak body enduring cautery in the middle of the head as we said, then cure the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you wish, administer the cautery which we said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a cautery having two knives.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 For indeed cauterization is better and more effective by this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 Chapter on the manner of cauterizing ear pain.
Caput VI.	 Chapter 6.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When there is pain in the ear due to cold and it is treated with solvents, and with the remaining cure as we said in the division, but the pain does not subside, then cauterize with fire: this is called a puncture, whose form is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then make small incisions around the entire ear, after its ignition (burning), as it is being rotated; or around both ears, if the pain is on both sides.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 Then burn the base of the ear slightly with the cautery after marking the spots with pitch; and let the size of the cautery be ten small points on each ear, and so forth.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then take care that they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterization for tortures.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 The torture that is cured with cauterization, is not other than those accidents due to phlegm, according to what we said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And let us avoid cauterizing the species that occur from exhaustion, and from spasm of a nerve.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When you cure this species of torture with hiruses (leeches) and purges (medications to expel waste matter) and gargarisms (mouthwash), and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you cauterize the weak one with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little below its time (a unit of measure), and third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your cautery on the weaker side of the affected area.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Since softening does not occur, unless in the healthy part that appears.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the shape of cauterization is to cauterize the same with a straight cautery at the base of the upper edge of the ear below the corner of the head, and another at its time (the point), whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 And place your hand with the cautery until a quantity equal to half the thickness of the skin has been burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 And this is the shape of a cautery and it belongs to the type with a blade (small knife), whose form is as follows: but it should not be too thin, as you see; and it is necessary that the blade is in it without being excessively thick.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then cure the location (area) with what has been previously mentioned until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for ancient apoplexy (sudden loss of consciousness caused by a lack of blood supply to the brain).
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When ancient apoplexy occurs and your treatment does not help with what has been previously mentioned, and the patient does not have a fever, then you should cauterize him with four cauteries over all of his cornus (horns) of the skull, and a cautery in the middle of his head, as we have said, and a cautery on the back of his head, according to what has been previously mentioned; and the method of cauterization should be as previously described.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 Also, it is cauterized over the mouth of the stomach with a cautery; and this is more ultimate.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then it will be cured, with what has gone before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 § On the method of cauterizing in obliteration.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that in a drink there are first, large amounts of hyssop, and purifying pills for the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then, shave the entire head of the sick person, and place on his head a plaster made from henna described in the plasters' treatise; apply it several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For that is the method of cautery: do it according to the same order as I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If he is cured by this (method), it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not (cured): then make three cauteries on the back of his head, which are descending from the top of his head to the lower part of his eye; place a thickness of finger between each cautery.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then, after care for the cautery, do as before (with the purifying pills).
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If you wish an additional treatment and the sick person can tolerate it: then make a cautery in the middle (of the wound or affected area).
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 And if you want an additional treatment: then cauterize it above both horns (of the skull).
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then, care for it until he is cured: and let the cautery be anointed according to the shape mentioned before (with oil).
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary that you proceed in the mundification of the head with hyson, and with what has been said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then scrape the head of the sick person: afterwards cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over all the horns of the head, and with a cautery over the back part of it, and three over the spondyles of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 If, however, you need the softening of the body by many of these things, and the sick person is weak and the illness is strong: then cauterize it with four cauteries over the spondyles of the back, and the last one with a cautery, until most of its skin is burned off, and let go of your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then take care of him until he is well: thus cauterize Olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 A person with epilepsy should not be cauterized, unless his epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you clean the brain of the patient first with hirses (a type of plant used for cleansing) and with the rest of the treatment as we have said earlier: when the patient is seriously ill or is resistant to medications.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 If the patient is a child who cannot tolerate medications, then gargarisma (a type of mixture) is administered and cleansing mastications are given to clean the brain before that for many days with good food provision.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head, afterwards cauterize him with a single cautery on the mid-point of his head according to what has been previously described; and cauterize another place on his occiput (the back part of the skull), and over all the horns of his head with cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 If the patient is strong and tolerant, then cauterize him with cauteries as previously described in the presence of paralysis, and apply mollification to his body over the spondylus (a type of vertebra) of the neck and dorsum (back part): and oil the cautery according to the method that has been previously described.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 If the patient is a child, then place a subtle cautery according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	 Chapter 12.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and gross phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries that have been mentioned in the presence of paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of slopes leading to melancholy and the body of the patient is damp, then give him a drink that cleans his brain, according to what has been previously mentioned earlier: then shave the head of the patient, and afterward make a well-centered turban from linen, similar to a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it in the middle of the head: and a weak person sitting square should hold it from every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then apply the liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 And it is more suitable from ancient butter of sheep.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat it above a fire with moderated temperature, as much as a finger can bear when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it from the middle of his head in a circle, and let it out until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this to the weak one once a week with the rest of his good regime, until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small holes in it, except that you should keep your hand with the cautery; preferably use something that smells good.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cauterization moistens the brain with its nature.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place on top of it a plate soaked in butter or goose fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 Chapter on how to cauterize when descending into the eye with water.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When you are informed about the beginning of water in the eye by the signs that I said in the division, then begin and clean the weak person's head with him.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him away from all moistness, and make him sit in a bath, for some days in fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then command him to shave his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his own head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then cauterize him on both temples with two cauteries, if there is no opening for the descent of water in both eyes at once: or from one side, if there is an opening of water in one eye: and cut with cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauteries be long in width like the temples: and avoid bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see something from it, then immediately cut it with any medicine that is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the removal of arteries, and cutting of them, and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes it is cauterized on the neck, under two bones, with two lastly produced cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 Chapter on the ancient method of cauterizing in tears.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are old and continuous: and they are above veins and arteries that are manifestly on the outside of the head, it is verified that this is from superfluitates frigidarum phlegmaticarum: then cauterize with the same cautery as I have mentioned in the opening of water, cauterizing in the middle of the head, and with two cauteries on both temples, and with two cauteries on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if it is necessary to add, then cauterize him carefully on all sides of the eye, above the edge of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in nasal stench.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you treat it (the patient), as we said in the division, and the medication does not improve: then rush and give infirmocochia for three nights; afterward shave its head, and cauterize it with a medium cautery, with oil-based cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then cauterize it (the head) with two cauteries and a medium cautery, on top of the eyebrows slightly beneath the hairs.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And take care not to cut the artery.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the form of the claw-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for softening the eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of the eye becomes softened due to illness or humidity, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, using this moon-shaped cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it (the head) above the eyebrows slightly in all parts with two cauteries; and they should extend from the temples; and let the length of the entire cautery be equal to the length of the eyebrows; and do not move your hand with the cautery, but rather according to the amount that is being heated, the third part of the eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of moon-shaped cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the eyelid when the hairs turn inwards and poke the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 The instrument (cautery) is of two kinds: either a hot cautery, or a cautery with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 For the hot cautery, instruct the patient to shave beforehand if he is one who cleans himself, until they (hairs) extend and become even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 If (they perform the cautery) at its origin: then bind his eyes with an ointment, so that they do not move, until they (wounds) grow.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 When they grow and become even, then place the head of the patient in your lap: then mark over the eyelids of his eyes with encaustic, marking that it is in the shape of a myrtle leaf; and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then place a warm vessel filled with egg white or slippery elm gum on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then heat the cautery, which has this shape.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize gradually on the marked places in many spots, until the surface of the skin becomes burned to a depth equal to the shape of a myrtle leaf in its entirety.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And the sign of your health is: if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting and hairs growing at the site of cautery.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then withdraw your hand: and release him for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then place a warm vessel with butter on it until the eschar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If some hair returns after an hour and the eyelid becomes softened: then repeat the cautery on that spot as you did before.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 If the hairs are in the lower part (of the eyelid): then cauterize it, until they grow back to their natural position; and it becomes even so that the hairs do not touch the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 Method of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	 Head Eighteenth.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 It is to be commanded to the sick person that he lets his hair grow until they become long and equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make a leaf shape out of paper from cloth in the form of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take from known soap and unmixed lime each a weight of an ounce or about that: then grind them together with good grinding, and make it quickly so that it does not become cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then, from that (substance) spread it out on the cloth you have made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it over one or both eyelids.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 Then pour the substance soaked in egg white onto a plate, and keep the head of the sick person in your arms.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 Place your index finger on the medicine, and press it slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 You move (the medicine) whenever the sick person feels the bite of the medicine, because its bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While it continues to feel that bite, then release the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When the bite subsides, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 Then consider if the eyelid rises like it is raised by heat or incision, that is good: and if not, then apply the medicine again to the same place where the medicine does not press and does not discolor, until your treatment is even and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place the substance soaked in butter on it until the skin of the burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with a diaphine ointment or another ointment until he is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 It is necessary for you to maintain the final protection during the operation so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If the eyelid becomes softened after a few days and something from the hairs falls into the eye, then apply the medicine again to that place where the eyelid is becoming soft itself, as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him until he is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that human eyes differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore, let your attention be on this: and the way of rightness for that which is devoted to this art should not be hidden.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 Method for cauterizing in lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	 Head XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When treating fistula, if the treatment as said in the classifications of diseases does not help: then it is necessary to cauterize it using this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Command the sick person to place his head in your armpit, and hold his head with a servant between his hands so that it is not moved or shaken along with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then place a cotton swab soaked in eye ointment or psyllium mucilage on his eye, and then apply the cautery iron of this shape (as shown below).
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 It is concave, like the form of a bird's feather quill at one end, with which you make a cautery iron: and if you want it to penetrate to the other end, or if you want it to point upwards in this way.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, it is better for your use that the concave part be towards the work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then squeeze the fistula if it is open and drain pus from it, and excise it; and if it is not open, then open it and drain its pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place the cautery iron on it, which has been heated very strongly.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand near the cautery iron from the eye to the nose so that your hand does not wander or the sick person moves; and you will place the cautery iron on the eyelid fat and destroy it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If, therefore, you reach the beginning of your cautery to the bone, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then apply the cautery iron once or twice as needed; and let it go for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then place cotton with butter on it, and treat it with an ointment of antiseptic, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 If they exceed forty days and are not cured: then place sharp corrosive medicine upon it until the bone is exposed; and shave it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And another method of cautery for the fistula, which some of the first called.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Stretch to the place of the fistula and close it; then put in its fissure a thin cannula, that is, a thin tube, whose form is as follows.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 Pour over it an amount of drachmas of melted lead, and hold your hand with good retention on the cannula, so that the weak one does not move at all, lest the melted lead reaches or comes to his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And it is necessary for you to place over the weak one's eye a warm infusion of eggs in milk, or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it with wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula is cured along with what we said from cautery, and with healing, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 And if not, then it is necessary to make a nasal opening and bring the fistula back to the course of the nose, according to what comes in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 [Chapter heading] On the method of cauterizing in fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	 Chapter XX: [Title not provided]
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Often occur on the lip fissures, which are called hairs, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 When you treat these fissures, with what I said in the division of diseases, and healing does not help, then make a small cautery iron in this shape.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its hollow be according to the fineness of a knife's edge.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then place it quickly into those cracks, until the cautery reaches the depth of the cracks.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with pitch until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 Method of Cauterization for a Mouth Fistula.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of a tooth, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts; afterwards it becomes old, and the pus runs and forms a fistula: then care for it, and do not apply treatment to it, then if necessary heat cautery according to its quantity, which can be inserted into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then insert the heated iron into the hole of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the hot iron reaches its depth and its end: do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then care for it afterwards, with what we said about treatment, until it is healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If therefore the pus separates and heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to uncover the place, and remove the rotten bone according to what comes out at its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 Chapter on Cauterizing in Softened Gums and Teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gums become soft due to moisture and the teeth move, and treatment with medicine does not help: then place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then heat the cautery, whose shape will come later, so that you place the cannula on a tooth: and insert into it the heated cautery hastily: and hold your hand for a while until the sick person feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And remove your hand: then repeat the cautery as often as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then let the sick person fill his mouth with water and salt, and hold it for an hour: and rinse himself.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 For a moving tooth is strengthened, and softened gums are tightened, and the corruption of moisture dries up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 Method of Cauterizing Tooth Pain.
Caput XXIII.	 De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium,
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When tooth pain is due to coldness or there is coldness within the tooth, or worms, and treatment with medicines does not help: then the Cautery is applied in two ways: either Cautery with butter; or Cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 The Cautery with butter is as follows: take butter and boil it in an iron cauldron or copper.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then receive the bandage and roll it over the end of the wound.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then immerse it in melted butter and place it quickly on the painful tooth, hold it until it cools; then repeat this process several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 And if you wish, immerse wool or a bandage in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth; then place heated iron over it until the heat reaches the depth of the tooth's hollow.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 The cauterization with fire is as follows: stretch out the probe made of brass or iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 Let there be something thick in his body so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the weak bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then apply the cauterization tool with fire, whose shape will come; place it on that tooth and hold your hand until the tool cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Repeat this process several times, as pain will disappear, either on the same day or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 It is necessary to fill the weak bone with good butter during the application of the cauterization and hold it for an hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 And this is the form of the cauterization.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Cauterize with whichever end you wish, according to what is possible; and this is the shape of the probe.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in abscesses.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter XXIII:
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When the boil is from phlegm and cold moistures and not obedient to digestion by medicines and desires digestion quickly: then to the hollow concave Cautery, whose form is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 Having two open extremities, so that the smoke may exit from the Cautery at one of the extremes: and place it (the cautery) heated upon the boil once, and again if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the boil.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the boil is small: then place the Cautery according to the size of the boil.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then leave it for three days, and place upon it a heated plaster soaked in butter, until what the fire has burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then care for it with tooth ointment until the form of the canal heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 § Method of cauterizing in throat hoarseness and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When moistures prevail over the canal of the lung, and especially when it is accompanied by coldness of the temperament, then the ill person should first be evacuated with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.
