Then cauterize it (the affected area) in the neck at the root of the throat in a depressed location: and beware not to reach the throat with the Cautery nor the skin, unless something of its (the Cautery's) effect is needed.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize it (the affected area) with another Cautery at the junction of the neck and shoulder blade in the last part of its end: and let the Cautery be like a nail according to the method described earlier.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what was mentioned before until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 § Method of cauterizing in diseases of the lung and cough.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	 When there is coughing and sickness of the lungs due to cold humors, and the person is not feverish, nor does he have consumption, and the sickness is old: then cauterize it with two cauteries above the clavicle in depressed, smooth, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	 With another cautery in the middle of the chest between two nipples: and let the cautery be cylindrical in shape, as was previously described.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	 And if your treatment is to puncture with a cautery named the Punctum, whose shape was previously described in the treatment of ear pain: and let there be punctures from thirty punctures up to another.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what was described before until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	 And now let the cautery have three branches in this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	 Because cauterization is applied with it, when you do it with one of three cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in Titillico, in the dislocation of the arm.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	 When the head is dislocated due to help [positioning], and it does not heal within an hour of returning from its dislocation, until that has become accustomed to return, then it should be dislocated slightly, which happens as we have already testified, at this point it is necessary to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	 Then the patient lies on his back or on a healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	 Then the skin is peeled, which is on the inside of the Titillico towards the top with your left hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	 Then fire is placed in a cautery having two hollows.
Cuius forma est haec.	 Its shape is as follows:
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	 Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the cauterization will come with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	 And sometimes the cauterization is with a cautery having three prongs, therefore the figure of the cauterization will be that of six cauteries: and these prongs are according to the subtlety of the tendon tested.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	 And this is the form of the cautery having three prongs.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	 And sometimes an additional one is added to this method, therefore there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	 Then place on the cautery compressed leeks with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	 Then make the sick person be still for peace so that a limb is not moved at any time until it recovers.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	 And if the dislocation is upward (and this seldom happens), then cauterize it with a curved cautery on the shoulder, or with many pointed cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	 For joining it becomes strong and moisture is removed; the sick person recovers.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter XXVIII (the twenty-eighth chapter).
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	 When cold and many humidities occur in the stomach, until it separates itself from its composition and produces many catarrhs for it, and continuous methods of treatment do not help; then the sick person should lie on his back, extend his legs, and stretch out his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	 Then cauterize with three cauteries, a cautery of the size of one finger under the concavity of the chest and a curved cautery on the shoulder, and two cauteries below the sides of one cautery, until a triangular figure of the cauteries appears.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	 And extend them apart so that they do not join together, when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	 And the depth of the cautery is the size of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	 And let the figure of cauteries be in this shape without addition. And if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this shape: and let the cautery that is made for this purpose be one in the shape of a circle according to this shape.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	 The stomach is to be cauterized by touching it with this cautery that frightens it. Let there be marks on the stomach at the point where you wish to apply encaustum. Then cauterize that point with the pointed cautery. Then care for it with the remedy that preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	 On the mode of cauterizing the epigastric region (frigidum).
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	 When there occurs in the epigastric region (Epate) pain due to coldness and moistness, or due to excessive gas, until it exits from its natural expulsion of superfluous matter and the patient is cured with what has been said, and it does not improve in this: then it is necessary that the patient lies down on his neck, and marks with encaustum three cauteries in this shape, and the same amount below the hypocondria, where a man's elbow reaches; and let the space between each cautery be of the size of a finger; and let the cautery be of the length of the body straight; and do not press your hand tightly with the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	 And let the thickness of that which is burned be according to the thickness of the skin, without any addition; and let the patient stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	 If he is not standing, then let him lie down who has already extended his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	 This is the shape of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	 It is possible for you to cauterize these cauteries with a pointed cautery when subtlety and wisdom are present in your art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	 "Take care not to proceed too far in cauterization, lest the entire thickness of the skin be burnt, for the body as a whole is burnt, and it reaches the intestines; since there the skin is delicate, therefore you know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	 "On the method of cauterizing abscesses of the liver.
Caput XXX.	 Chapter XXX.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	 "When it happens that an abscess is about to burst and one wishes to know whether it is within the flesh of the liver or its membrane; if it is within the flesh of the liver, there is a dull pain without sharpness, and if it is in the membrane of the liver, with a very acute pain: and you see that the treatment has become tiring.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	 "Therefore the patient should lean forward on his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 "Then mark the position of the abscess with a hot iron, and then heat an iron similar to a probe.
Et haec est forma eius.	 "This is its shape (the probe).
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	 "And cauterize with the probe until the entire skin is burnt and it reaches the pus, until all the pus comes out; then treat him with care for bursting abscesses, until he is cured.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	 "And one should not use this method of cauterization, unless one's study extends to the art of medicine; and through whose hands these diseases often recur with experience: then he may dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	 "But it is better to let it be (the abscess), in my opinion.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	 "Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	 "The ancients said that a probe with the roots of Aristolochia should be used for cold pleurisy in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	 "And it is to take a dry and long root of Aristolochia, one longer root which can be found among them, and let it be as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	 Then immerse her in oil and burn it in fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	 Then cauterize it with a single cautery where the neck meets the shoulder, and with two small cauteries on the areas slightly below the chin, in that region under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	 And with two more cauteries on the area between the fifth and sixth ribs towards the back, and another cautery in the center of the chest, and another one above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	 And with three more cauteries from the back: one where it is between the two scapulas, and two more on both sides of the chest, with the lower cautery where it is between the two scapulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	 And you should not press your hand with the cautery, rather let it smell of skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	 And some ancient men have said that there are those who use a cautery made of iron resembling a rod and burn it inside the chest until it reaches the same place as the boil, and the pus comes out, just as we said in the case of an abscess in Epates.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	 But in this perforation with the cautery, there is a fear that either the sick person will die immediately or a fistula will occur in a place where healing cannot be achieved.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	 Chapter 32: The method of cauterizing the spleen.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	 When you treat the illness of the spleen, as we said in the treatment of diseases and your treatment does not work, then cauterization is to be done in this case in three ways, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	 One is to make three or four cauteries in a row along the length of the spleen according to the shape of the cauterizations described earlier [in the book].
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	 And let every cautery's size be that of a finger's thickness, more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	 The method of cauterizing the liver, as we mentioned earlier, should be equal on both sides.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	 And do not press your hand with the cautery: let it be weak and prone onto its backside.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	 Another method of cauterizing is: having heated the cautery with two openings, as we mentioned in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder; and peel the skin, which is directly above the spleen, where the weak arm arrives; let your peeling be along the body's width, so that the cauteries fall along the body's length.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	 Then introduce two openings heated very strongly, until they penetrate the skin from one side; then remove the cautery; thus there will be four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	 And if you wish to cauterize with a cautery having three openings.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	 Then care for the cautery after you have released it, let it emit pus for many days; for this is more conducive than the other treatments that preceded it in healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Hydropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	 A cautery does not fall in Hydropsy, unless it is properly applied.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	 When you treat a Hydropsy with the methods of treatment we mentioned earlier, and it does not improve, then you must cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, one on the stomach, another on the liver, another on the spleen, two behind the loins, and one on the chest and another on the stomach; let the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	 Then release the open cautery, so that it emits pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	 And it is not right to evacuate the sick from treatment after cautery, for it is necessary that two intentions are gathered towards him: and healing will hasten towards him with divine aid.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	 The form of the cautery for the abdomen should be clavilis; according to its preceding form. And the form of the cautery for the back should be oliuaris; according to its preceding form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing Feet and Legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	 When they are amputated in Hydropico and filled with citrine water: it is necessary that you cauterize on the back of the foot at the navicular bone, which is between auricular and annular; then remove your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it. Then remove your hand. Do not go back to it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	 For citrine water will flow out, and let the cautery be in this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	 Then make two cauteries on each leg, and let the cautery be at the end of a cultellar cautery throughout the entire leg; and let the cautery be along the length of the leg, one below the knee, and the other lower than that, about half the length of the leg. And over the whole hip two cauteries; and leave the open cautery without treatment for a long time: until some water flows out of it; then cure it with what we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing for the solution of the abdomen.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	 When the solution of the belly becomes loose due to cold and moistness, until it weakens the powers retained and digestive, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with methods of treatment, but it does not heal: and you see a person enduring an excessive force of heat, then cauterize him with a large cautery on his own stomach, according to what has preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four subtle cauteries around the navel, with a subtle claw-shaped cautery: and a cautery over alum on top of blisters large or with two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	 If you see excessive moisture and a person enduring it, then cauterize him with a cautery on his chest (pecten) and on the whole hip: and perhaps you may add two small cauteries near the large one on the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	 For indeed, this treatment is progressing, of which the benefit does not wander off.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	 When in the anus there are many old hemorrhoids or one, and they are made of thick fluids, cold or corrupt moistures, and they are treated with what we have said before, but treatment does not improve: then cauterize them with three cauteries on the lower part of the loin under the flank slightly triangularly, and with a cautery under the navel as if two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And if you think that his stomach is cold and food is not digested, and you see his face becoming pale: then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery, according to what has preceded: and with a cautery on his liver (Epar), and another one on his spleen (Splenem), with a cautery claw-shaped (clauili): and leave the open cautery for some time: then treat him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	 On the method of cauterizing the althelul after their excision.
Caput XXXVII.	 Head XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 When you excise althelul (a type of tumor or growth), then apply a burning cautery similar to a rod.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	 Then introduce the burning (cautery) into the excised althelul; and withdraw your hand until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows; do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	 If there are many althelul (tumors or growths), then cauterize each one with a separate cautery as we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	 Then take care of them, applying to them the remedy that is used for them until they heal.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	 And if you cauterize it with a large cautery on alcatin (a type of stone), this is more beneficial for the treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	 On the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Head XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	 When the sick person does not obey the incision and operation as we have described in its place, and is afraid of it, perhaps he will heal with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	 If a fistula occurs and discharges pus and becomes corrupt, cure it.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	 It is necessary to test it as it should be, with a probe of subtle material.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	 Then find out the depth of it by means of a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	 Then heat the cautery which is like a rod.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	 Then insert yourself heated (into) that fistula and find out the depth to which the probe has penetrated.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 Then repeatedly apply the cautery to it until all the corrupt bodies are burnt up, once, twice, or thrice, according to the necessity of your case.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	 And be careful not to burn the nerve or the large vein (if it is there); or if the fistula opens up to the bladder or the intestine, then be careful of these places altogether.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	 And do not make that (action), unless when the fistula is in a fleshy place; and consider that it does not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for the place until it has healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	 If, however, the place is sealed and the materials are cut off from it and remain for a long time; then you will know that it has healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 If the materials do not fall off from it, then you will know that it is penetrating, or that a rotten bone is at a deeper part of it, or something like that; whose memory will come back to its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX (39).
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	 When pain in the kidneys occurs from cold or from thick wind, and it is weakened by this disease of the body, then it is necessary to cauterize it above the flank on both kidneys, with a cautery over the entire kidney with a cautery claw, whose precedent has been remembered.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	 And perhaps we cauterize it again in the same flank.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	 Therefore, three white lines will come.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	 Thus, there will be more relief in the latter (stage).
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	 Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	 When weakness and softening occur in the bladder due to cold and moisture, so that it does not hold urine properly, then cauterize it in the lower part of the abdomen below the bladder, where the pubic hair begins, with a cautery on one side from the right side of the abdomen and another on the left side: let the length of this cauterization be according to the size of the knuckle of the thumb: and cauterize it with a lower back cautery, or two cauteries if necessary: and let the preceding cautery be as that of the claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing the uterus.
Caput XLI.	 Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When coldness and moistness occur in the Matrix (womb), and it is forbidden for conception because of this, and its menstrua are corrupted, and the summoning of them is delayed, and there is pain at their approach, then it is necessary that it be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and with a cautery below on the back, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery be a claw.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	 The Method of Cauterizing the Womb in Dislocation.
Caput XLII.	 Chapter XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	 When the mucous humors flow out to the perineum of the womb and become the cause of its displacement from its place; and the sign of this is that one leg is extended over the other when they are brought together: and a gap or void is found in the place of dislocation.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	 Therefore, it is necessary to cauterize the weak spot above the perineum of the womb with a similar cautery in a circle; after you have marked the circumference of the perineum with hot iron, as is customary: and that the perineum falls into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	 And let the cautery be of the same form as the one used in cauterizing the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	 If this cautery is not at hand, then cauterize it with three cauteries, using a large lard-caustery; and the depth of the cautery should be in proportion to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	 The Method of Cauterizing for Sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	 When pain occurs in the ankle joint, and its cause is coldness and moistness: and the sick one is treated as mentioned before, but it does not improve, then that should be allowed to heal by itself: then it is necessary that you dissolve the sick person from thick humors with foul pills or artificial pills, and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	 Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	 And the method of cauterization is according to two modes: either cauterization with medicines applied, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	 Cauterization with fire, is according to many modes.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	 One of these modes is that you cauterize over the ankle joint with three triangular cauteries in this manner.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	 And make their depth good or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	 And let the space between each cautery be of the thickness of a finger: and let the cautery be covered with oil.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	 Sometimes however, a cauterization takes place in the middle of the ankle joint itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	 Therefore there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	 And if you wish to cauterize with a ring, whose shape preceded in the ankle joint dislocation, one: so that the ring encompasses the entire ankle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	 And burn off the thickness of the skin entirely.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	 This is the method of cauterization in sciatica, when the pain is attached to the ankle itself and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	 If it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries on the hip, at the place where the sick one indicates, in which there is pain, and your cautery four fingers on the outer part of the shin: and let the cautery be a knife-shaped one.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	 If the sick person indicates that the pain extends almost to the toes of the foot, then cauterize it there where he indicates with a cautery, with one, two, or four, or more, if necessary.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	 If he indicates that the pain is turned towards the leg below the knee, then cauterize it there with a one-edged cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	 And be careful in every cauterization of yours, that you do not burn the nerve or the great artery, and attract harm to it through this, or contracture.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	 And I myself have seen one and another, from those who cauterized above the ankle, and burned too much in the cauterization, and the leg became swollen until the tumor reached the foot, and it was perforated completely, and the whole foot was corrupted: then the abdomen burst open, and death followed this.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	 If the pain is in two parts at once, cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	 And some wise men said in cauterizing the ankle, that this is the method of the cautery.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	 Make a small crucible of iron, whose diameter is half the size of the palm: and it should be at its mouth according to the thickness of the nut of a thumb or less: and inside this small crucible there should be a third small crucible.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	 And let the space that is between every crucible be as much as the size of a knuckle: and let the crucibles be open from two sides: and let their height be like a knuckle, or two knuckles: and make handles for them from iron appropriately placed in the crucibles.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	 Then it is heated in the fire until it turns red and throws sparks: then it should be placed on a potsherd of the ankle, with the sick person lying down on his healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	 Cauterize it therefore with three round cauteries at one time.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then let him go for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	 Afterwards pack it with butter and let the open wound heal for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	 Albucasis says, we have not used this kind of cautery enough, because of the horror of its appearance; and therefore, because few are found who can bear to look upon it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	 Nevertheless, it is one of the good cauterizations for him who can endure it and finds a place for it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	 The cautery with medicines driving it is, you shall make two small bags containing a perforated armillary, from which descends the key of its door made of bronze or iron, as long as the height of the wall; and on the height of these there should be two knots, or as if they themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	 And the space that is between the two should be of the thickness of a finger and they should be open from below and above; and it should hold each other according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	 Then place it on a box with an anchor lying upon the sick side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	 And press your hand much upon the box with the anchor.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	 Then pour water between the two circles which has been heated a little by fire and hold it as much as an hour's time; and let the sick bear the biting of it and its burning, for he himself finds the biting like that of fire, until the biting ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 Then wash your hand with the tool and clean the anchor completely with warm water and sweet water; then let it go for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	 And place butter upon it until the blackness of burning is removed; and let it go for some days, and pus will run out from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	 The remedy is at last in aid.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then apply a cure with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	 If the pain spreads to the hip or leg: make a splint for him in such a way that it contains water, as you did in the case of the broken bone equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	 And this is the method of hot water: I have already written about it in the treatise on rectifying remedies.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	 Take two parts of lime and unburnt plaster, grind each separately; put them in a new pot whose lower part is pierced with a small hole, according to the amount that will be added to the radius; place another earthenware pot underneath; pour over it lime and plaster from sweet water, so that both are submerged by about a finger; press them down with your hand; let go of the pot, until the sharp water goes down to the bottom of the earthenware pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	 Then gather that water entirely, and pour it over another mortar; and grind, until it returns.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	 For that very reason it will then be strong and highly sharp, which is administered in many medical operations, and in the cauterization of other members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	 Because it makes the action of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	 And among the medicines, with which they are cauterized (or burnt), such as tartar emetic, also strychnine, and almond oil with soap, in such a way that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	 And indeed, Galen relates the story of a certain man from the ancient times, who was cured of the pain in the anus and the sciatic vein; and he greatly praised his cure.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	 And he said that it did not require any other treatment, and that he was cured from the pain in one application, until he reported that perhaps he himself entered the bath, and came out already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	 And it is to be taken from green seitarag; and if green seitarag is not found, dry one should be taken, recently; and it should be ground very much with a little fat, and placed over the anus, where there is pain, or thigh, or hip; and it should be tied, and allowed to stay for three hours, or until the sick person feels the relaxation of the burning sensation.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	 Then introduce it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	 When his body becomes hot, introduce it onto a bed.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	 For the pain subsides, and he is cured.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	 And know that no one should use a cautery with these medicines unless after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	 And Dioscorides himself said that the feces of goats, when with it the sciatic vein is cauterized, should be added to it; and a cautery is made according to this method.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	 Take flax (or linen), immerse it in old oil, and place it over the deep place which is between the big toe of the foot and the sole, and is closer to the sole.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	 Then take dried goat droppings, heat it over fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	 Place it on the flax and let it burn out (completely).
Deinde itera illud.	 Then do this again.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	 Do not cease to do that until sensation arrives through the mediation up to the ankle, and the pain stops.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	 And this method of cauterization is called Vaccinum cauterization (or branding).
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	 Chapter on cauterization for back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	 Whenever there is back pain due to various causes such as fall, blow, excessive evacuation, and similar conditions, due to the infiltration of cold and moist matter; cauterization only applies in this specific case, which is done by the infiltration of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	 Therefore, after evacuation (bowel movement) of the sick person with foul-smelling pills and similar things, three lines should be drawn on the back where there is pain, following the width of the palm; after marking each line with encaustic in five cauterizations or more depending on the quantity that comes from the strength of the patient; and make cauterization by cauterization puncture.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	 And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauterizations along with the medial claw shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for humpback (kyphosis).
Caput XLV.	 Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	 This illness often occurs in small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	 The sign of its beginning in children is that it happens above them with a constriction during inspiration at elevation, and you find it at the bottom of the spine of the back and the nodes of this part, which has already begun to appear over the other spines.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	 When you see it and wish to treat it, then cauterize it with a cautery that is in the shape of a circle.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	 The cautery should catch the entire spine part equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the spine with a pointed cautery, do two or three lines, and let the points be close together.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	 Then care for the place until it heals as we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	 And beware not to administer the cautery on a hump that is formed from a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	 Chapter on Cauterization in Gout and Joint Pain.
Caput XLVI.	 Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	 When the pains of joints are caused by cold wetness that is poured out to any part of the body, then when pain occurs in the feet, according to medical custom, it should be called gout properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	 When gout caused by cold is being treated with methods of treatment and the pains do not subside, then cauterization removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	 And it is that you should cauterize him after evacuation around the joint of the foot, with many cauteries: and let the cautery be Olive Oil.
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	 And if you need to puncture the sole of the foot, then do it with a pointed cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	 If the pains ascend to the knees or other joints, and it often happens this way, then cauterize it over all the knee with three or four cauteries from every side, with the same cautery of Claw.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 If more than one are necessary for you with this cautery, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	 Do not immerse your hand in the cautery, rather let it be about the thickness of the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	 If the pains rise to the knees and back, then administer what was said about cautery in its own chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	 If the pains are only in the hands, then pierce around the circumference of the nails, as two lines are rolled up.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	 If pain remains in the fingers, then pierce them all, over every knuckle and over the back of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	 If pains rise after days to elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	 And do not evacuate the weak from good management, from receiving medicine.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	 For if there is good management and phlegm is evacuated, it will be cured with the help of God with this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	 When there is a rupture in the groins and the intestine or yarn goes down to the testicle, and it is close by: then one must order that the weak person should abstain from food on his day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	 And let him use laxatives so that stool comes out of his stomach.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	 Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and order him to hold his breath until the yarn comes out or the intestine appears.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	 Then bring him back with your fingers, and mark with a hot iron under the rupture on the back of the hand with a sign whose end is similar to half a circle above the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	 Then heat the iron cautery in this form until it becomes white and throw small pieces of charcoal onto it.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	 Then reduce the intestine, or the hernia to its hollow.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	 Then place the attendant's hand over the location so that the intestine does not come out: and you have already opened between the limbs of the sick person, and placed a retractor under it, and another serving on his limbs, and another on his chest who holds the hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	 Then place the cautery over that mark, with your hand holding the cautery upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	 And hold it until you follow the bone with it; or repeat with another tool if you are not able to follow it to the bone in the first instance.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	 And be careful to observe the exit of the intestine during your cauterization, lest you burn it and bring harm upon the sick person or great misfortune occur.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	 And know that when you do not follow the bone with the cautery, the operation is of no benefit.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	 And it is necessary that the cautery for children be delicate, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then take care with the remaining ointments until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	 And let the sick person lie on his back for forty days until the wound is healed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	 And it is necessary to give him nourishment for the duration of his treatment, which will soften his stomach, lest the intestine come out during attempts and evacuations.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	 Then when he wishes to rise after forty days, then administer a well-made ligament and let him hold it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	 And he should be diminished in labor, and in food and drink intake, and in violent speech.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	 For when he is subjected to this regime, he will heal completely.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	 And I shall speak of the treatment for hernias with incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	 When hernias occur in the remaining abdomen, and they are beginning and wish to be stopped, then cauterize the hernia with a round cautery according to its size; and let that which is burned be as the third part of it from then on.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	 Then take care of yourself, as I have said, and do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	 And some first ones said: that a rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautionery, in this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	 After it is signed with hot iron, and a line is placed that runs through the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line towards below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	 And place your hand in the middle with a nail-like cautionery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	 But the first cautionery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing for pain due to rupture or trauma.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	 When pain occurs in some limbs due to rupture or trauma and the pain persists for a long time and there is no cure with medicine, then it is necessary to be cauterized with a cautionery of puncture point.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	 And the cautionery of all members should be according to its size and its smallness, and its weakness, and its power, and the location of torsion, and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	 If he is cured by the first cautionery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	 If not: then apply another cautionery on top of it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	 Because by the custom of these pains they are changed from one member to another that is closer to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Therefore you should follow them with cautionery until the weak one is cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing for leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	 The leprous, however, are sometimes helped by great cautionery.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	 And especially the species of leprosy that comes from rottenness of phlegm and melancholy: when it is considered to cauterize it itself.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	 If leprosy is beginning and it has been treated with what was said in the division, and it does not decrease nor stop: and fear that corruption will spread over the entire complexion of it: then cauterize him on top of his head with five cautioneries: one in the middle of the head known, and the second below it towards the forehead at the end of the hairline, and two above the two horns, and one behind the nuchal bone.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	 Place your thumb lightly on the cautery until it makes a small impression on the bone, and the cortex should dislocate: to relieve the expiration of large vapors from it, and cauterize also over the spleen as previously described.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	 If however, the leprosy has already spread over the sick person and is clearly visible: then it is necessary to cauterize with those cauteries that were mentioned earlier in the head, and with a cautery on the tip of the nose, and with two cauteries on both cheekbones, and with two cauteries on both shoulder blades, and six on the hip bones, and one large one over alhahosos near the tail and one on it, in the same almeidati: and with two on the ankles: namely, on each ankle with one, and with two on the thighs, and two on the upper arms, and two on the elbows, and two on the tendons of the chest, and cauterize it over all the joints of his fingers of both hands and feet, and cauterize over every calcaneum of his feet, and burn the palms of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	 Be careful with the nerves that are above the last calcaneus to avoid burning them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	 And sometimes the cautery is applied on the forehead, and another on the stomach, and another on the ebar.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	 And know that, the more you apply the cautery, the greater the benefit and the stronger it becomes.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	 And know that, the sick person does not feel pain from the cautery as healthy people do; this is because his body has already become numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	 It is necessary that the cauteries be of different sizes and shapes according to the members and joints; this is based on the types of iron instruments as previously described.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then, prepare a cautery from wheat flour and honey, and for the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	 Method of Cauterization in Sleep.
Caput L.	 Head of Leon [Albucasis].
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	 When a part of the body is numbed (stupet) and treated with medicines, oils, plasters, but does not heal, then cauterize the affected part using cauteries, according to the size of the member or its diminished state.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	 And let your cautery penetrate slightly into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with an ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	 And when cauterization is performed for certain numbness that occurs in the hand and foot, in the spine at the nerve exit point moving that limb; and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	 But do not presume to perform it (cauterization) on that unless the one who knows about the structure of the body and the course of nerves moving the body is wise.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	 Chapter on Cauterization in Albaraz.
Caput LI.	 Chapter LXI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	 When Albaraz (a type of wound?) becomes old and does not receive anything from the arts of medicine; then cauterize it with a deep cautery slightly, according to the thickness of the skin, until the white disappears and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with wheat flour and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossa (a type of fern), and blood of a dove and of a heron; each part should be equal; mix all these together, spread them on a cloth, and let them adhere to the location until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	 Chapter on Cauterization for Cancer.
Caput LII.	 Chapter LXII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	 When cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with a circular cautionery around its circumference, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	 The wise say that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	 I, however, do not find that to be so: because I fear that it will burn, and I have already seen that happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	 It is truer, however, to cauterize it around its circumference with a circle, as we have said; or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	 Chapter LIII: When someone has Adubelati that is slow to mature, either because of excessive production or due to weakness from old age and scant blood supply, or because one wishes to hasten the maturation of Adubelati, then cauterize it around its circumference with many small cauteries by puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	 Then let it be.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	 For it will hasten when matured.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	 If you wish to perforate it with cautionery, then ignite the cautionery, whose form is as follows:
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	 Place it [the instrument] in the middle of Adubelati, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery that follows be weakened, so that its course may be purified.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterizing in a corrosive disease.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter LIV [The forty-fourth chapter].
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	 A corrosion is not anything except corruption walking in a limb and consuming it, just as fire eats dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	 If therefore you see a corrosion in a place that can bear a cautery with fire, then apply much cautery, small and large nails, according to what suits the place where the corrosion is located.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	 Then cauterize it from all sides until you eradicate the entire corruption and nothing remains of it deep within.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	 Then let it be for three days and place finely ground sulfur with oil on the cauterized places until all scabs and all corruption are eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	 Then care for it with ointments that promote flesh growth.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	 If therefore you see that after three days flesh is born in a healthy way, in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery on what remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	 A corrosion is sometimes treated with an acidic medication.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	 The corrosion itself arises where the cautery was.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	 However, a cautery with fire is more effective; and I myself have said that the cauterization of it with an acidic medication is used in division; so take it whenever you need it there.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	 Chapter on the mode of cauterizing in nails and warts.
Caput LV.	 Chapter LV [The forty-fifth chapter].
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	 This illness often occurs in the lower parts of the feet and it is a thick, filtered matter that injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	 The cautery is indeed of two kinds: the cautery with fire, and the cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	 As for the type with fire, it should be made similar to a bird's talon in shape: which is to be made of iron, according to its size that contains a nail from all sides; and it should be fine at the edges.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	 Then place the heated [tool] on the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	 Then turn the hand with the cautery around the nail, until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail; and leave it for three days, until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	 Then apply ointment with forest herbs, crushed with salt; and leave the ointment on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	 It will be rooted out by its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for the place with a gentle ointment until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	 If they are not converted and occur frequently on the surface of the body, particularly in hands and feet: then administer cauterization with hot water; and it is to be had that you take a cannula made of copper, iron or bird's feather; and place it on the nail, or althea.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	 Then pour a small amount of hot water into the cannula; hold your hand and turn it with pressure for a short time, so that the tip of the cannula is pressed onto the root of the nail, and let the hot water find its way to the depth, to the root of the nail: and wait briefly for the weak one over the bite of the hot water for an hour.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	 Then leave it, for the nail will be rooted out with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	 Thus do this one after another, until you come to all who are on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	 Then care for them when they have been rooted out, with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	 Method of Cauterization During a Shake/Tremor.
Caput LVI.	 Healings for wounds of the head which are incurable by
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	 If a tremor occurs from cold in the nerve or from quartan fever or another cause, then it is necessary to cauterize it with four or five cauteries on the dorsal vertebrae, and between each vertebra with a cautery, and in its chest with a cautery, and over its stomach with a cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	 The tremor is quieted when the cautery is applied to oil, and health from cold illness hastens.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	 Method of Cauterization of Albathir.
Caput LVII.	 Si accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in ner
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	 Sometimes the foul Albathir are expelled from the body, that is, pustules which are made from corrupted gross matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	 Therefore, when they appear, it is necessary to cauterize over every head of the pustule with a subtle cautery and myrtle wood whose tip is burned with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	 Or with the root of the long aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	 Or with a lenticular cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	 And sometimes they are cauterized with a small piece of raw meat, at the beginning of their expulsion according to this method; and they are not increased; and superfluity is broken causing them to be expelled, and they heal from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	 However, it must be done after the evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 Method of Cauterization for Bleeding from an Artery in a Wound.
Caput LVIII.	 Si in ulnere alicui accidit fluxus sanguinis
