Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	 And the knowledge of the methods of this art is a testimony to the methods of diseases: then indeed you will find that which is suitable for each disease among the instruments.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	 I confirm to you the number of instruments at the end of this chapter, which you place as examples upon which you cut, and the proof by which you test others.
Forma Serrae.	 Form of a Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	 Form of another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 Form of another Saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 Form of another Saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	 This form of a saw should be well made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	 Make the upper part of its arch sharp and the blade from iron, and the handle from boxwood, and let it be well made in the shape of a pyramid.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	 Form of a Scraper for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	 Let the head of this Scraper be in the shape of the head of a star-shaped nail and its points be shaped like the points of an elongated fork.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	 And it is not suitable unless it is used to scrape the joints when they are broken or a large and thick bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	 Form of a larger Scraper.
Forma medii Rasorii.	 Form of a medium-sized Scraper.
Forma Rasorii lati.	 Form of a wide Scraper.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 Form of a Scraper with a concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 Form of another thin Scraper.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 Form of another Scraper with a curved end.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 Form of a small, fine Scraper.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 Form of a Scraper for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also the form of a large Scraper.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 This resembles a saw and its end is like a saw: it is used in many places for the scraping of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 Form of the Razor that suits its purpose, which has been made from bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 The end of it is triangular and sharp-edged.
Fit ex Indi.	 Made from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And similarly, it is necessary that all the things I have said be made of razors, scalpels, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 On the incision of limbs, and the sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 Limbs become putrid either from an external cause, or from an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 If you have treated the corruption with medicinal treatment and it does not improve: and if you see that the corruption is advancing into the limb which has not been affected by anything: then it is necessary to make an incision in that limb until the point where corruption reaches, so that the sickness can be expelled through it either from death or from a greater evil caused by the loss of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign of this is that the limb turns black until it is thought to have been consumed by fire or has become rotten after turning black: until the rot spreads until the point which follows the limb and creeps throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Therefore, when an incision is made and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the sting of some poisonous creatures such as sea scorpions, weasels, hedgehogs or similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If corruption or a sting is in the limb of a finger, then incise the finger and do not leave any space for the corruption to advance until it reaches the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And similarly if this occurs in the hand, then incise it from the root of the palm and do not leave any space for the corruption to advance until it reaches the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it penetrates into the arm, then incise the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If however corruption passes through and you see him about an elbow: then in that case is the death of the weak.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And to administer beyond that in treatment, is quantity virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And similarly do with the foot, when corruption invades a toe; then cut it off at one node: and if it enters into the heel of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 If however it rises to the knee, then cut off the leg at the juncture of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 If however corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no remedy in it except for abandonment and leaving the weak to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 And the manner of cutting a limb or sewing it is that you tighten the ligament below where you wish to cut, and then tighten another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And stretch one minister ligament downwards; and stretch another minister ligament upwards towards the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And you separate the flesh that is between two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the flesh is entirely exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then it is cut or sewn.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And it is necessary that you lay linen cloth over all the parts, so that the knife does not touch a healthy place; and an additional injury is added to the weak, and a warm abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 If however there is a flow of blood internally while you work, then burn the place quickly; or lay on it some powders that absorb blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you what happens to a man in his foot; the same thing happens that I am telling you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 That is, because blackening happens in the foot as a result of burning that resembles fire burning; and corruption first occurs in his toe, until it began to involve the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 The man cured himself, after he saw corruption occur in a limb with great severity, which he discovered from pain and burning: and he cut it off at the joint, and he healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And when a long time had passed for him, that same corruption happened to him in the index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 Therefore he came to me, and I attempted to regain that loss with him by placing medicine over his hand after cleansing his body: but the loss was not gained back, and it started to spread to another finger: until corruption began in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 So he called me to cut off his hand: and I did not want that, hoping for recovery of the loss from me: and I also feared death itself for him at the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Since the man was above his loss.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 Therefore when he gave up hope in me, he returned to his own land: and it came to me about him, because he acted quickly, that he cut off his entire hand: and he healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I did not bring this narrative, except to be of help for that which falls under the nature of this illness: and to be a signification, and according to which it should be done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 Chapter on the treatment of sinuses, and the quality of cleansing with medicines.
Caput XC.	 Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When a boil occurs in some fleshy parts and the space of the boil extends until it collects pus: then it breaks or perforates, and what is inside the pus exits, and there remains an empty place as if it were a vessel: and the skin that is over it like a cloth that has been softened: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, nor presses on the bone, nor on the nerve, nor on the ligament: it deserves to be called a sinus: and it is not called a fistula: but if the space of it extends until the corruption presses into one of these parts, then it is called a fistula or a zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 The care of it is that you cut the entire skin as it rolls out; and especially when it has been refined and made like cloth; and trust that it will not adhere to the place due to its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 If you expect the skin to adhere, and that is not due to the ultimate corruption; and if there is a thickening of flesh in the skin, then treat it with Clisterium; and it is necessary to consider towards the Anus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 If it is large and there is pus that smells foul from it; then clisterize it with the Egyptian medicine which is vinegar, oil, and zinnia, taking equal parts, mixed together in a vessel; and boil it over fire until the medicine turns red; and let it come to the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take from it what is necessary for you; and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize the Anus with it; and tie up its opening, and let the medicine remain there for a quantity of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then remove it by pressing; make that day as many times as necessary until the Anus is cleansed, and the foul smell removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And sometimes clisterize with water and ash, when this medicine is not present for you; and it is necessary to take ashes from vine wood or ashes from holly trees; and pour water over it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then boil it, and clisterize with it until you trust that the Anus has been cleansed.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the sick person cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine or water and ash, then clisterize it with water and honey to which something of crushed zinnia has already been added.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or clisterize it with honey and wine mixed together, since the property of honey is to cleanse and wash; and wine makes the Anus adhere, especially when there is an excess of stiffness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you do that several times and trust that the sinus corruption is already removed: then cleanse it with it, along with what causes flesh to grow within it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And you should take from the plaster dyafinicon: and you will dissolve it with rose oil and stiptic wine; or cleanse it with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written about in the treatise on unguents.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the opening of the sinus is narrow and a cannula cannot enter it to cleanse it: then widen it slightly with iron; or place linen wrapped in Egyptian ointment or basilicon ointment within it until it becomes wider.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the opening is also wide, then bring together its lips with stitching; and allow the amount that the cleansing agent can enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the opening from which pus flows is raised to a higher place: then cut it in a lower area that is within it, so that the pus may flow out towards the lower part; since pus when constricted at depth prevents flesh from growing within it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible for you to cut the sinus at a place below as desired: then try to prepare a body part so that the pus may flow out from there easily, according to your preparation.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try not to retain anything at all from the pus within it; and take consolidating medicines that are placed on the wound, appropriate for what you desire.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 Spread them out on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 Let the linen cloth be of such size that it will provide communication for the entire sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors directly through the opening of the sinus a hole larger than the sinus opening itself.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread a soft ointment over another cloth, according to the size of the opening; and place it on top of it, positioning it far from the orifice of the Sinus, so that the exit of pus from it is relieved; and do not remove the large cloth unless after several days, instead.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 The one who is over the orifice of Sinus, that is the one you remove at all times, so that what accumulates in it may come out; and that you know if what runs out from it is much or little; or digested, or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And when this is done again, consider the place of the Sinus itself, whether its master feels pain in it, or not; and if there is pain in it, whether it is an abscess, or not an abscess.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 When therefore your medicine is thus applied and you see the matter that comes out from the orifice of Sinus, then you know if the Sinus already adheres or approaches adhesion; then solve it in the morning or on the third day; and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 If, however, a subtle venom comes out from the Sinus after a long time, then do not despair of its adhesion, for healing of it is approaching; since there are people who have a slow generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act against this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 If, however, undigested pus comes out from the Sinus after several days, then you know that the Sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If, therefore, the adhesion of Sinus is delayed and prolonged; then add in the drying treatment of medicaments; but let the physicians do this so that the medicaments are wet in substance, and dry in effect; such as unguentum dyafinicon, when the excess is added to it from zeug.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the last one to be treated is this: to receive the ointment of dyafinicon, and it shall be dissolved with rose oil, and it shall be grinded upon it an equal quantity of ancient wine in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then mix it up together, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And now makes a similar action when you do not have the ointment of dyafinicon at hand, honey, when you cook it until it thickens, and use it instead.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or receive myrrh, and aloe, and frankincense: grind all of it, and powder it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then apply linen cloth over it, and bind it with a bladder: and line it with the honey you cooked, until it thickens; and powder the substance over it, and place it again on the linen cloth, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And sometimes administered in it are long alexanders, the roots of celestial lilies, and is lily: also wheat flour, and chicory.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them plain or combined, grind them, and sift the powder: and powder it over the honey I mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 If the case of the bladder extends and is not cured by this treatment: then you will know that corruption is deep within it: either it has made an impression on the bones or in the hard parts, or ligaments: then cure it by the treatment of fistulas, as was mentioned before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 Chapter on the care of ulcers and scratched nails, and incision of fingers, and amputation.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter CXCI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Ulcer under the nail of the thumb or big toe, and perhaps in other fingers is called panaritium.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 When its duration is prolonged and neglected in treatment and cauterized with heat, it may become corrupted and discharge pus until it rots the nail root; and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone, until there is a foul smell; and the tip of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When you treat it as I have said, and your care does not do so: then it is necessary that you shave with iron the entire superfluity that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 Indeed, cautery is very helpful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 If the bone is healthy and the nail is also sound, and empty additions of the nail now press the flesh towards the inside and begin to pierce it, and wound it: then it is necessary that you put fine radium under the corner of the nail which pierces the flesh, and push it up; and cut the flesh easily, and put on top of it what remains of the flesh from burning medicines, corrosives, until it is removed completely.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 If the corruption has already penetrated the bone, then it is necessary that you cut out the bone, and remove it; for it will never heal as long as corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 If you see the corruption and decomposition advancing towards the finger, then cut it at one node, according to its previous description.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 If the nail happens to be rubbed or struck, and a strong pain occurs, then it is necessary that you use the leech first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with a sharp spatula crosswise from above to the desired length.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And be careful not to let the incision reach the flesh that is under the nail, for you will cause a violent pain to occur on account of it, and it will become a cause for the growth of additional flesh at the site.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then take care of the place so that it alleviates the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 The finger that is born in some human hands may perhaps be entirely fleshy; and perhaps some of them have bones, and perhaps there is a nail in it; and some of them are born at the joint, or its growth occurs in some knots of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 Therefore, the one that is born in some knots of the finger does not move; and the one that is born at the joint of the finger may perhaps move.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 The dissection of the fleshy one (of the fingers) is therefore easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 This means to make an incision at its root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 But the treatment of the one whose growth is at the root joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore, refrain from making an incision of it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 In the one that is born at the end of the knots of a finger, then it is necessary to make an incision in the first place through a round cut up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then saw the bone with one of those saws that fit for this purpose.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 The consolidation that occurs in fingers often occurs either from the birth of a person (that is, it is born with him), or from a wound consolidation, or burns by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, it is necessary to cut off that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place linen or gauze soaked in rose oil between them to prevent them from consolidating quickly, and separate them; or place a thin lead sheet between them until the site heals as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if consolidation happens to certain fingers with the palm, then cut that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and suitable for the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 Chapter on Defects in Incision.
Caput XCII.	 Chapter CXII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Uites are swollen veins filled with melancholic exudates that occur in many parts of the body; and most often they occur in the legs, especially those walking much and suffering, and those carrying heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 Therefore, it is necessary to administer a strong purging of the body from black bile at times.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then perform venesection on the patient's basilica vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 The cure of these (varicosities) with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One method is to make an incision and draw out black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 The method is also that a vein is raised and drained completely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The section [of the vein] however, is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 Firstly, apply a poultice on the leg with much warm water until the thick and foul blood is resolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then tie the diseased leg from the upper part of its thigh to the lower part of its knee with bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein at one, or two, or three places with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then drain the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg upwards, and it is necessary that a phlebotomist firstly attends to the diseased person.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail downwards: until as much blood comes out as you see sufficient, and as much strength the diseased person can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Then tie it and command him to abstain from foods causing black bile; and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and that does harm to the diseased person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The method of draining is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Shave the diseased leg if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then immerse it [the diseased part] in a bath; or apply poultice on the leg of it with warm water until it turns red and the veins swell up; or exercise it with strong movement if there is no bath present, until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then make a straight incision along the vein, along its length; or at the end of it near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with knives and scrape off the vein from all sides, until it becomes visible; and at its appearance, it turns from red to black as if in a downhill slope.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it comes from the skin, it appears white like a sinew.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then introduce the Radium under it until it is raised and comes out of the skin; suspend it with a blind hook, softly.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then cut another section near that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then scour the skin above the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then raise it with Radii as you did before, and suspend it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then cut another section or several sections as needed.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then raise it up and make an incision on the last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then pull it out to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 And do this until you pull it out from the section above or higher sections, until it comes out completely; then make an incision on it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 If it does not obey you to pull and raise, then insert a needle with a strong thread and tie it and pull it out; or insert a Radium under it; turn your hand around all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful not to cut it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it becomes very difficult for you to raise it up and a harmful thing enters the patient from it.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you pull it out completely, then put linen soaked in wine and rose oil or olive oil over the wound area and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If the vein is twisted with a curved shape and has coiling in parts and not as we said in a straight manner, then you must cut across it in all its curved parts and the points of coiling itself.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then suspend it with hooks until you raise it up completely; be careful at your cut not to cut the vein or wound, for it will be difficult for you to raise or pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The form of incision to heal a wound.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 Form of excision for cataract.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It is not like other incisions in sharpness nor has a pointed end to avoid damaging the vein; and it is roundish and flexible, not too fine because if it were too fine, it would cut the vein with its fineness; rather, there should be excess roundness as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 Extraction of the leg vein.
Caput XCIII.	 De lactatione infantum et veteribus mulieribus.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in warm lands such as Alizegi and the land of the Arabs, and in dry, hot lands with little softness, that is, where no herb or tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And indeed its generation is from putrefaction which occurs beneath the skin, just as it happens within the bodies of snakes and ascaris worms, and worms generated between skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And the sign of the onset of this vein is that which occurs from a heated inflammation in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then it is incised.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein begins to emerge from that incision place, as if it were a root of a tree or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When that end appears, then it is necessary to wind around it a piece of lead weighing one keil dram, up to two drams and knots; and allow the lead to hang from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something emerges from it towards the outside, wind that up in lead and knot it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it extends too much, then cut a part of it, and wind up the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut it at the root before it has emerged entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 Since if you cut it, it contracts and enters the flesh; it causes an abscess to occur, and pus in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it should be treated gently and drawn out gradually until it emerges from the end of it, and nothing remains in the body from it; and this vein emerges from certain people that is five palms long and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has reached me, because the man has emerged from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If it is cut during your treatment time: then insert a probe into its hole and perforate it with a long rod until all that is in it from the matter is evacuated; and administer the putrefaction of the place with medicines for some days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then treat it with treatment for boils (or abscesses).
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And indeed this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many openings occur to it, and a branch leaves from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore treat it as we said in the section on ligature and with what was mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 Chapter on Surgery of Worms Generated Under the Skin, and it is called Boil Sickness.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter CXIIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This disease is called Boil Sickness in certain lands among us; because it often occurs in cattle and a small worm is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it moves throughout the body, ascending and descending; and it is felt by the senses during its walking from limb to limb until it bursts wherever it bursts in the skin and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 And its generation is from the decay of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 As worms and snakes, that is earthworms and roundworms occur in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 And it is feared from its malignity.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it moves in the body and rises to the head and reaches a place, then perhaps it opens there and comes out, and destroys an eye; and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 When one wishes to treat it and extract it, then this is not done unless during its walking and appearance to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 Therefore, tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If it goes deep into the flesh, and you do not find it; then place a cautery on the spot with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 The greater fear is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If you find him (the wound) already advanced near the eye, then tie a good ligature below it (the wound).
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it and extract him (the foreign body).
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 The sick person must use cleansing of his body with medicines that dissolve corrupt and bad humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let him beware from foods causing corruption.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 Chapter on the incision for Nakir's disease.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter CXV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This disease is called Nakir in our land, and it is pain that occurs in certain members, then changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And indeed, I have seen it myself, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And she pulled back her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after staying for an hour, I saw a swelling moving with the thread, like a worm, rapidly ascending to her shoulder as fast as possible; so that it was like live silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 The pain withdrew from that place, and it was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then sat for an hour, and ran through the rest of the body, until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then he told me that he was turning over his whole body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 Therefore, I marveled at the speed of his exchange from one limb to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And indeed before that, I had not seen this illness in my eyes in such a manner as I saw it now.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 Nevertheless, I have seen many who find pain to be transferred from one limb to another; and I myself did not see it as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think it to be anything but because the woman was from those who are from dry villages with brittle veins; hence, it appears that the windiness was transferred.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that it does not appear according to this reasoning in those who are delicate and bodies with moist veins; hence, the concealed veins should not be considered.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Therefore, if you wish to heal him and the patient feels that pain; then, if it is visible to you as we have said, then press upon it quickly and beneath it; cut above it, until the windiness confined there is expelled; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If, however, you do not see it with your eyes: then heal him by pressing the body and that which expels windiness, and drive out the windiness with stinking pills and pills of serapion, and similar things.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 Chapter on Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter LXVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 The arrows are diversified according to their kinds and the places where they fall on the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 The diversity of ears is as follows: because there are some with large points, and small ones; concave ones, and deaf ones.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And there are those that have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And from these are tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And from these are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 These, however, which are according to the limbs on which they fall, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 Or the limbs are hollow from main limbs, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidney, intestines, bladder, and similar ones.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When it falls on any of these limbs and appears to you as signs of death which I will tell you later, then it is necessary that you draw out the arrow from them, for death follows him where it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these signs are not visible to you and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then draw it out yourself and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 The sign of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates the bone and exits from the siphac (a membrane covering the brain) is: because such symptoms occur from it as sudden deafness, scotoma (diminished vision), vertigo, redness in the eyes, inflation, redness of the tongue, spasm, confusion of intellect, and vomiting of cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 Blood may come out from the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 Speech may be cut off and voice destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 White moisture comes out from the wound place, like dough.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And it comes out from there resembling a watery consistency of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If those signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment, and remove the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of an arrow when it falls in the heart are: that it is near the left nipple; and it feels as if it were fixed in a hard object, not in a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps the arrow has a movement similar to the pulse's movement; and blood runs black from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And this is followed by coldness of the limbs, cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Therefore, know that death approaches without a doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 The sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is the exit of frothy blood from the wound; and the vessels that follow the neck should be cut off, and the color of the patient changed.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And it exhales a large, deep breath; and it seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls into the pleura, which is in the chest; then it is near the small ribs; and there is a great panting with violent pain, with sighing; and all the limbs of the shoulders are moved.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 If the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 If the arrow falls into the abdomen and becomes fixed there, something like feces or bile or a ruptured intestine comes out from the wound.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore, there is no hope for treatment or removal of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If the arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out; and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger than the patient; then know that it is deadly.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The remaining limbs, as the face, neck, throat, spatula, assistant, vertebrae dorsales, pelvis, leg, and similar members are saved according to several arrangements; when the arrow does not find an artery or nerve; and the arrow is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you what I have seen about these arrows, so that it may signify to you concerning your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 This is, because a man fell down with an arrow into his tear duct of the eye, at the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore I extracted it from the other side, under his ear fat: and he was healed, and no damage happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which fell to him in the fat of his eye under the lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not get anything more from it except its small end, which adhered to its wood: and the arrow was large among the arrows of the Turks, with a soft iron, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore the Jew was healed, and no accidental evil happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I extracted another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 And the arrow was Arabic, and it had ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 Therefore I cut above it between two cartilages: and already it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 Therefore I sharpened myself with it until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I extracted another arrow from a man who fell down with it into his abdomen: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 Afterwards, after thirty days had passed and nothing changed in his condition, I cut above the arrow: and I opened it up over it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no accidental evil happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man who fell down with an arrow into his back, and the wound had consolidated on it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 Afterwards, after seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	I saw a woman who had an arrow fall into her womb, and the wound healed upon her, and the arrow remained within her; and none of her conditions were changed, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 I saw another man to whom an arrow fell on his face: and the wound healed, and it remained, not causing him much pain; and similar things happened many times.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 I removed an arrow from a prince of the King, which had fallen on his nose, and it had already deviated slightly towards the right; and the arrow was entirely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 Therefore, I was called for his treatment after the fall of the arrow, up to three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 Therefore, I found the arrow wound very narrow.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 I therefore asked her with a thin probe, and she did not feel it; and he himself was finding a puncture and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore, I hoped that this puncture was from the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 Therefore, I dressed the place with an attracting and digesting plaster, confident that the location would come out and a sign of the arrow would appear for me to cut over it; but it did not happen at the place where it was expected, indicating that the arrow had missed its mark.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I therefore continued with the plaster over him for many days; but it did not happen as expected, and the wound healed in the meantime; and the man remained weak from its extraction, until one day he felt the arrow within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I therefore applied sharp and corrosive medicine to that wound for many days until it was opened; and when I probed it myself, I felt a small end of the arrow adhering to wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added the sharp medicine in the wound opening until it became clearly visible to us the end of the arrowhead; and it passed with that space of time approximately four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 After the wound was opened and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move it, but it did not obey and came out; then I did not stop refining and devising ways on it until finally, on a certain day with properly made forceps according to the shape that comes at the end of the chapter, I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed the physicians judge that the nose cartilage cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore restored it, and the wound healed, and the illness became whole again; nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you about the quality of some arrow extractions; in order to put this rule and meaning on what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Because the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended with the narrative; nor does the book contain it, and the wise artist compares a little about much; and with what is present, concerning what is absent: and he finds a new operation, and a new instrument for descents of foreign matters in this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 Therefore I say that arrows do not come out of the limbs to which they are fixed, except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by attraction from the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or conversely, by the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And what comes out from where it entered is either a proceeding arrow in a meaty place; and it is attracted and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 If it does not obey to come out at the hour when it falls; then it is necessary that you leave it for some days until the flesh around it putrefies; and the attraction of it will cease, and its coming out will take place.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly, if it is fixed into the bone and does not obey you to come out, then leave it for a few days; and repeatedly it with attraction and motion every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 If it does not come out after a few days, then it is necessary that you bore around the arrowhead in the bone from all sides with a subtle drill until the arrows are expanded.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then draw it out and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head and has already advanced into one ventricle of the brain, and there appear some of those symptoms that I have mentioned: then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and leave it until its humour becomes equal on the following days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if the arrow reaches the siphon, then death does not prolong for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed except in the body of bone only and does not penetrate up to the siphon; and remains weak for several days, and no symptoms occur from it: then apply your skills in drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 If it is fixed deeply and does not obey you to draw out: then apply drill around the arrow, as I have told you; then take care of the wound until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow is already hidden in the body and concealed from sensation: then search for it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments that are suitable for drawing it out.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot apply pressure on it because of the narrowness of the wound and the length of the arrow in deep: and there is no bone, nerve or vein there; then mark it until the wound expands and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If there are ears he must hold, then freely remove the fixed flesh from them on all sides, with every skill you can, and skills, if it cannot be done by dissection of the flesh due to a fracture of the ears or their twisting, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 When you perform an extraction of the arrow, wherever it is, then use twisting with your hand, along with tweezers in all directions, until you make it come out: and with subtlety of ultimate subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and the attraction of it becomes difficult for you, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot do it by the hour, then leave it for some days until what is around it putrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then repeat it: for the tunica will soften. If, however, the flow of blood opposes you, then administer what I have said in its treatment as mentioned in its chapter: and guard your skill from cutting a vein, or a nerve, or a tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer your skill in every way possible for the extraction of the arrow: and let it be with facility, calmness, slowness, or firmness, as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 It is necessary that, when you pull the arrow, it should be weakened according to its shape, according to which it was at the time of the arrow's accident.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible from the shapes.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 The arrow that comes out from the opposite part or already proceeds to the outside, or makes a hump at the end of the arrow by the sensation of the skin on the upper side and you see it bulging: cut above it, and the cut should be according to the amount that the tweezers can grasp.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then pull it out: for it is easy to come out by itself.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If it remains in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness until the arrowhead impresses into the bone and expands; then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: let it be for a few days; then draw it again until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the arrow shaft is wooden in it, then force it out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 If the arrow shaft fell out, and force is to be administered: then insert a concave instrument into it so that its concavity enters the shaft's tip; then force it with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If the arrow is concave, then force it out with the inserting instrument.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 For the arrow is loosened by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out all the flesh where the poison is: if it is possible for you to do so.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then care for it with what is suitable for that purpose.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If the arrow falls into the chest, or the abdomen, or the bladder, or the side: and is near where you can reach it with a probe, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut over it, and avoid cutting the vein, or nerve, and remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then sew up the wound, if you see one, and take care of it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the form of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The tips should resemble a bird's beak, which have been made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And they are made in various shapes, large, small, and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow, its smallness, and the width and depth of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 Form of the Probing Hook concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 And the form of the Probing Hook for the deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the tip of the probe similar to a radius, so that it can be relieved into the concave arrowhead and pushed along with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The tip of the probe is concave like a bird's feather, so that it can be relieved into the arrowhead itself and pushed along with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 Chapter on Phlebotomy of Veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter XCVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 Veins for bloodletting, the custom of which runs in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 From the head there are sixteen: two pulsating veins which are after the ears, called the two Herbs: and two arteries which appear in the two temples: and two veins which are in the two tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called Watchers: and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead: and a vein at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two jugular veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 The veins that are to be bled in the arms, are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is the Cephalic, and it is from the side of the woods; and they call it by the common people the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 And Black.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And the Middle one, and it is composed of a branch of the Basilica and a branch of the Cephalic; and they call it by the common people the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And Basilica, and it is placed on the domestic side; and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And they call it by the common people the vein of the abdomen.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And the cord of the arm, and it is placed on the elbow; and that is the one which is bled, and that is the one which appears above the thumb with a clear presentation.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And Saluatella: and it is the vein which is between the wrist and the little finger; and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 The one of them is which is a curvature under the nail of the thumb from the side of wood.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 And the second one (is) Saphena: and its place is at the heel, on the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And vein Nessus: and its place is at the heel, on the wilderness side.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And in the other limb (there are) three veins similar to those (mentioned before).
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 [Title: On bloodletting of two veins after the ears.]
