Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 The bloodletting of the two veins that are after the ears is beneficial for ancient catarrhs, and for hemigraine (headache), and for scrofula (tuberculous swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck), and for old maladies of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of bloodletting (it) is according to what I have said (in previous text).
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 And (it is) to shave the head of the sick person: and his back of the head should be rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth rubbing well.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then the sick person should bind his neck with ointment until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 And their places (are) after the ears, in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Therefore seek them with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, there mark it with a hot iron (branding).
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take the bloodletter (phlebotomist) with a cutting instrument (cultellus), and that one is called 'The One Who Cuts'.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then insert it (the cutting instrument) into the vein under the skin, until the bloodletter reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then draw your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut (make a shallow incision) in the vein along with the skin.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be the size of two fingers joined, or about that: and make as much blood come out as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then bind it with sutures, and let it heal by itself.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now begins the first part of the book: incision and cauterization [of the affected area].
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Chapter on the venesection of two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 Venesection of the two arteries in the temples is beneficial for an old headache called hemicrania; and it helps for sodium praua, obtalmia assidua, and excess discharge of sharp fluids to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the method of venesection should be as I have told you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 The sick person should bind his neck tightly until two veins appear clearly to the touch and their pulse is felt under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then you will mark them with a heated iron.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then scrape the skin above the vein with your index finger and introduce the lancet under it, and scrape the vein towards the top.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And cut it as you did with the two other veins, and let it bleed according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 Then loosen the constriction of the sick person, and place your finger on the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Afterwards place a cloth over it and sutures, and bind it tightly; then let it heal by itself.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now ends the reminder of these [procedures], and their incision and extraction, at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 Chapter on venesection of the forehead vein after venesection of the temporal veins.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 The benefit of venesection of the forehead vein is after venesection of the temporal veins, for old facial ailments; and for headache, redness, and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 The quality of phlebotomy [is] as I have told you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 Compress the sick neck with a poultice until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take the instrument called Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its shape [as follows]:
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Place the sharp point that is at the top of the Fossory over the same vein, and strike it with a chisel or with something else in the same manner; and allow blood to flow according to the amount you desire.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then solve the wound of the sick person, and bind it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes it is opened with a broad leech.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However, it should not be the sharp-edged leech, as the other leeches, but rather the broad-edged one.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 And the leech should be applied across (the wound) because the bone is nearby; and perhaps it will break when it is sharp.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 Chapter on the Phlebotomy of Veins in Two Lacrimal Ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 The remedy for the two veins that are in the two lacrimal ducts of the two eyes is for the eye affected by scabs and redness; it is applied to the eye itself, and to the diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 And the quality of the leeching of these veins is that the sick person should bind his neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then apply the leech to them; and you be standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 And make the leeching across (the wound) to a length less than the width of the leech with a small leech and a broad one slightly smaller; because there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 If the leech is sharp-edged, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 Then let blood flow from the wound as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 Place a piece of cloth over them and bind them overnight; and then unbind them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 Chapter on the Phlebotomy of the Nasal Veins.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The veins of the nose are useful for treating acute fever, violent sore throat, diseases of the face such as headache and redness which occurs on the face; especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 The quality of phlebotomy in this case is to tighten the sick man's neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold his nose with your left hand and take a fine, long phlebotomy needle; and fix it in the middle of his leper's snout, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its correct position.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 Since the vein is not visible there and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 It is necessary that you hold your finger with the phlebotomy needle a little: and make the blood run according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 Then tie it up at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 For it heals quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 Chapter on the Phlebotomy of Veins (Guidi).
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 Guidegi's two methods of phlebotomy are beneficial for the constriction of coughing, and the onset of leprosy, and melancholic diseases, and impetigo, as well as bad ulcers, and those that corrode, namely herpetic sores or scabies.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 The quality of the phlebotomy is to tighten a sick person under both necks with a band; and the worker stands above the head of the sick man, and the sick man sits on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 Then the vein is to be phlebotomized at a length slightly larger than the width of the phlebotomy needle.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then draw out an amount moderated or according to what you see, due to necessity for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Then untie the band and tighten two veins with a constrictor; so that the sick man does not choke.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And release it until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 A wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 Chapter on the Phlebotomy of Veins (Algeberich).
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 Algeberich's veins are beneficial for phlebotomy because they contribute to alcohol in the mouth, and decay of gums, as well as bad ulcers, fissures of the lips, ulcers, even those that are in the nose, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 The quality of phlebotomy is that you make the sick person sit before you: and tie his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Then roll back his lip, and look at the two veins: one is on the right side of the lip, and the second is on the left: and the demonstration of each is by the blackening of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 And that is true: because around them are small, dark veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Therefore make an incision on each with a cutting incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 But if there is doubt about you and you do not know which one it is: then direct yourself to the larger incision, and that will be more obvious.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And similarly, do the same with the two veins that are on the upper lip: and certainly there is a common custom with it: and make an incision of the two veins that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 [Paragraph on Phlebotomy of Sublingual Vein After Cephalic Phlebotomy.]
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 But of the two veins that are under the tongue, the help for phlebotomy is: because phlebotomy of the cephalic is for swellings that are in the throat, and sicknesses of the windpipe, and sicknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 And the quality of phlebotomizing them is that the sick person sits between your hands facing the sun: and clean his tongue, and look below the tongue on one side for a vein, and on the other side for a vein: and the color of each declines towards blackening.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 Therefore phlebotomize both: and be careful not to injure your hand while phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 For there are arteries beneath it, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 [Paragraph on Three Veins in the Elbow.]
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are phlebotomized in the elbow, are in whose phlebotomy a common custom runs in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 And phlebotomy of these (things) is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 It can be done either by pricking with a broad-bladed leech (myrton): or by applying oil to the puncture for thinning: or by cutting with a sharp-edged lancet (cultellus), and this is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 Thus Alnesil is what is suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And among these (things) there are broad and thin forms according to the width and narrowness of the veins. The form of the leech (myrton) should be broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 It is suitable for opening hollow veins that are full, projecting, apparent, thick and those that contain thick, cloudy blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 And this leech (phlebotomus) is smaller in width and more delicate for thinning (extirpation).
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 It is suitable for the phlebotomy of fine veins that contain subtle, yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 Chapter on basilica phlebotomy.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 The basilica vein (one of the three) is a help for phlebotomy (bloodletting).
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it draws blood from the ailments that are under the throat and neck, because it follows the chest and abdomen; it is suitable for the leech (phlebotomator) when he performs phlebotomy on it, to be careful, and to beware of it since below it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If (the leech) therefore errs and adds in the puncture of the leech, he will cut the artery, and there will be a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 Therefore, the leech (phlebotomator) should not prick it with a leech: rather he should cut it with a lancet (Alnesil).
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the basilica is not apparent with a clear manifestation, then it should be sought out and exchanged for another or a branch of it should be sought: or if no branch is found, the leech (phlebotomus) can take the arm in its place.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 The matter is evident, and cut it with the leech Anesil, as we said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If you wish to perform phlebotomy on the same, then it is necessary before tightening the arm, so that you touch the place, until you know the place of pulsation.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 Then mark the place with pitch, afterwards the arm, and cut the vein with a concave knife by the leech Alnesil, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And beware that the blow does not fall into the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 And when you see, while tightening the ligament, swelling at the place which you marked with pitch, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery; therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood springing up at the phlebotomy, like a boy's urine, and it is subtle, red: then you know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 Therefore approach, and place your finger over the same space, afterwards remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If therefore blood is cut (many times it is cut), then tighten the arm and let it go; and beware the weak from moving it; let there be fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And do not move it for some days, until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 If however blood is not cut, and it beats you; and if medicine is not present to you at the moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For its ends contract, and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or take the bark of a fig tree, and fold it; take half of it, and tighten it over the place of vein tying, with a ligament and wool until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 Then if blood is cut off, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 And if not [the case]: then care for the self with him to whom it preceded, the remembrance of the place from which powder-producing drainage flow is abscinding; and the cutting off of his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the smallness of the wound's location, and the possibility of ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 The Treatise on the Bleeding of the Dark Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 However, the bleeding of the dark vein is beneficial because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body; for this reason, since it is composed of a branch of Basilica and a branch of Cephalica, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 Furthermore, it is suitable for the bloodletter to be cautious about it, since there is a nerve beneath it.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 Therefore, if the bloodletter adds too much during the bleeding and finds a nerve, there results numbness, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps he will not recover completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 And this nerve often appears to the sense of touch.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 If it is concealed in some people and is subtle and does not show itself, then you must place your bleeding where you bleed her, with the incision of Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with all your might.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 If the vein is between two nerves, then pierce the vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 The Treatise on the Vein of the Head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 But the bleeding of the vein of the head is beneficial because it draws blood from the head and contributes to eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 And it is suitable for this vein in particular, if you wish, that the bloodletter should anoint it with oil or myrtle while bleeding, since it is safer than all veins, because it is not beneath an artery, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 It is appropriate for you in bloodletting that you ask the barber to take only the head of an arm, and seek a softer spot; it does not harm him if no such place is found at first strike, that you should repeat on it with bloodletting several times.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 Perhaps an abscess occurs in some people when they are not bled at the first strike, but it does not harm him that abscess.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 Chapter on the usefulness of bloodletting and precautions to be observed.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The nature and circumstances of bleeding, and those matters about which you should think for correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 Firstly, know that bleeding is not administered unless for the preservation of health and persistence thereof, and caution against the onset of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 And bleeding should be done in one of the three veins that are in the elbow, namely the cephalic, the radial (fusca), and the basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 And bleeding should be done at the beginning of spring after fasting, during summer and autumn, and winter after eating when signs of filling appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 Bleeding should be done on the first or third day, after three hours have passed since the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 However, bleeding administered in illnesses has no determined hour; but whenever it is necessary and appropriate for that purpose, it may be done at night or day, and in any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 It is not necessary to bleed children until they reach the age of fourteen.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 A pregnant woman should not be bled from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 The elderly who have passed sixty years should not be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 When someone wants to be bled for any reason, it is necessary that they clean their intestines with a mild enema before the bleeding if there is much retained feces in them; so that dirty, harmful fluids from the intestines do not attract veins at the time of bloodletting and harm the main organs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 The patient should not be bled when he is in a state of satiety or nausea: neither the drunkard, nor one coming out of drunkenness, until that (condition) has been removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 The sick man should not be with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 Care should be taken not to bleed again after a colic attack, vomiting, diarrhea, increase in sexual activity, labor, exercise, wakefulness, fasting, and any other thing that weakens the strength of the body or the animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 Then consider in detail about the fluids before that (bleeding), if the blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medications; if possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 Then enter a bath, if it does not forbid him something; or exercise in some way to make the blood thinner.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And put the bleeding of his in the chest, around the third day, as we said; and strive to make him expel his chest on that day from all animal ailments: such as suffocation, anger, fear; and from all bodily ailments, such as labor, punishment, excess, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 And let him sit with the things that are in use by human custom for their aroma, scent, fragrance and similar things in quantity according to his ability.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 Then let the bleeder sit on a higher place than the bleeding couch; afterwards he shall draw his arm out and rub it with his own hand twice or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 Then tighten the bandage with a cord and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the bandage be moderate, because if the bandage is not equal or too tight in the binding, then it prevents the flow of blood; or if it is too loose, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 Then after the ligature (stricture), it is necessary that the phlebotomist rubs his hands together simultaneously, until the veins swell, and they become apparent to the senses.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 Then the phlebotomist cleanses (the instrument) for phlebotomy with a little oil, in an ancient and proper way.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 Then he places his index finger of the left hand on the same vein at the place where he wishes to do phlebotomy, barely: so that the vein does not escape and the blow is cushioned (absorbed).
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Since the veins are like strings fleeing during phlebotomy and from them is that which is full of windiness; and when you place the phlebotomizer upon it, it contracts under the phlebotomizer, and the phlebotomist is deceived, and does not open the vein: and if he opens it, it is ligated; therefore for this reason it is necessary that the phlebotomizer be firm and attentive in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 Then he places down (the instrument) the phlebotomizer.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If then a vein is opened from one side, it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then do it again on the other side in the same place barely or above it with haste; if the spot is not pierced through (repeatedly).
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 If it is pierced through or frightened by the weak, then dismiss him for a day or two; and do not tighten the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Perhaps (the wound) will attract an abscess that is hot.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 Do not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 Then repeat the phlebotomy, if it is loved (desired).
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 If the opening is small or the blood flows thinly; and be careful that the amount of blood which you wish does not escape from the blood; then repeat the phlebotomy in the same hole according to correctness, and add slightly in the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 Make it quickly before the location is removed, for the location to be removed is in many people during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If you see it already removed, then do not go over it at all, for nothing exempts you from it in your presence.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 And place something made of oil over it: because it soothes the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 It is better in this place than the oil itself, and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 Similarly administer the ointment of oil in every phlebotomy of yours, where you let blood against the flow of blood: and they do it with Tyrian alfarach, and sageza, when one of them is placed over the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 Blood becomes subtle and dissolves when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If it happens in the place of phlebotomy a large abscess, for it often happens, especially to one who is not a phlebotomist except on that occasion, or it is a small opening of a vein, then hurry and place over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated slightly: and tie it for an hour: because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 It is necessary that you do this after the blood has come out from the vein itself, when it has completed its flow, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If something remains in the place after several days that is black or greenish, it does not harm it: and if you wish, place over it something of aloe, or myrrh dissolved; or something from the juice of mint, that is, calaminthe or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 And indeed abscesses and protrusions often occur in the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Therefore place your hand over it, then if you find softness under your pressure on it, then that protrusion is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 Carefully place something from what I said upon it.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 Perhaps blood from the artery will flow out of it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 Make an ointment for it with that which has styptics, so that it may harden the place.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with the rest of the treatment until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 It is necessary to draw blood from every man according to the quantity of its virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And what appears as a boil on top of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 If the blood is black, then let it come out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it come out until it becomes more subtle; and similarly if it is sharp, let it be removed until its sharpness disappears.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 It is necessary for the one who is full and strong, and needs to have blood drawn once, that the vein cutting be amplified; and let him be a vein cutter with one side; and it should be opposite for the one who is weak.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 It is necessary to draw it out in veins and that the hole be tight; and it is better when administered in vein cutting that it be a cross section, not a prick.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 This method of vein cutting is safe from the flow of blood and from the cut of a nerve; it is more praiseworthy and safer than vein cutting by width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 And whoever is accustomed to come for vein cutting with fainting, it is necessary that he eat a little bread soaked in water of grape-juice or sekanjabin if he is heated; and draw blood from him in three or four veins.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 If she is of cold constitution, then let her take before vein cutting bread soaked in syrup of honey, or in syrup of aromatized honey with spices, or in fragrant aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If bleeding occurs during phlebotomy (bloodletting) and it is caused by excessive blood flow, then one should take meat water and fragrant syrup of subtle strength, and use aromatics with alum, and apply linen to the chest with it; and use the rest as mentioned in the division on syncope from the chapter on evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 If one wants to empty his arm and let out blood, and the phlebotomy is due to a large evacuation and its strength is weak, then he should let out the blood gradually by the amount of its strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 But if one wants to empty his arm and let out blood, and his body is probably: then he should do this after seven or nine hours from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 If one wants to draw blood from his body to the opposite side to which it inclines, then it should be done on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 In a body where much blood has already become heated and sharpened, and it makes fever occur: it is necessary for the blood to be expelled from him once, and a large quantity to be drawn out; and the opening should be enlarged until syncope occurs; after you have observed all conditions of phlebotomy; and that you place your hand on the pulse of his arm along the course of the blood, so as not for death to occur due to syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 For it often occurs when the phlebotomist is unaware, and it falls through negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 And it is not necessary when you want to empty the arm and let out blood on the second day, if the opening of the vein is already closed, and the outflow of blood becomes difficult, to press upon it with violence and to stretch it quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 That is very bad, rather let it be, until it is bled a second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 Remove with the sharpness of the lancet that which has clotted from the blood in the vein's opening, and place something dissolved in salt water upon it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 And place upon it some turban or alfaroch, or saffron, and apply gentle pressure until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 If it is already a vein that has been cut, then let it be, and do not cover it up, until the abscess settles down.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 If there is a need to let out blood a second time and there is no excuse, then either make an incision over the same place or in another vein of the arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 The arm's vein is bled at the place of the Fuscus and Basilicus, as they are not found and are hidden because they are composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 The quality of bleeding is such that a weak hand is inserted into hot water until it turns red and the vein appears clearly manifest.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then bind it above with a string of moderate tightness.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Then bleed it again by transverse incision slowly, neither wide nor long; and let the opening be wide, and let your bleeding there on the joint of the hand.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 If the outflow of blood is prevented, then dip your hand into hot water and let the blood run into the water until you meet your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 But if it is during the days of summer, then you are excused from dipping your hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 It is indeed recommended that the course of blood be let in hot water during winter time.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 This vein's bleeding is safer than all other veins because there is no pulsating vein or nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 Phlebotomy of the right hand (Salvatella) is for the afflictions of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 And the quality of its phlebotomy is that you tie the little finger of the hand with a ligature or your hand after inserting it into warm water until the vein becomes inflamed and it is clearly felt.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then make an incision across (it).
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 And if you cut it completely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 And preserve (it), lest you cut off your hand with the phlebotomy instrument.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 For under it are the nerves of the fingers exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then put your hand again into warm water and let blood flow there.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 For if you do not repeat it in warm water, the blood will clot in the vein opening and stop flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 Therefore when you extract from the blood a quantity necessary, then put oil and salt on the vein so that it does not clot quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And likewise it is necessary that you do this with every constricted vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	 But the aid of this phlebotomy is from the left hand, because it is for the afflictions of the spleen; and do likewise with its phlebotomy as you did with the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	 And the aid of the saphenous vein phlebotomy is for the afflictions that are in the lower part of the body, such as the afflictions of the womb, retention of menstruation, and weaknesses of the kidneys, and old ulcers of the hips and legs and similar afflictions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	 And the quality of its phlebotomy is that an afflicted person puts his foot into warm water; and he should do rubbing on it until the veins swell up, and tie above the joint of the foot with a strap.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	 The location of the vein is near the heel, appearing towards the thumb; and many branches originate from it on the sole of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	 The vein therefore should be tapped in a larger branch of it, or at the heel in its cluster; because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	 If the vein is to be tapped on the sole of the foot, then take care not to touch the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	 Place your lancet for tapping the vein at an angle across it, as if you wish to cut into it; and let the one who taps the vein be called Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	 If the flow of blood is prohibited, then immerse his foot in warm water; and let the blood run out into it until it has emptied.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	 If the vein is accidentally missed by the one who taps in the first instance, then let him repeat with the lancet towards the upper part, for it is a safer place, and there is no danger of harm, provided you take care to avoid the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	 Similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The location of the Sciatic vein, as we have said, is near the heel on the side of the woods.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	 The aid for tapping this vein is to relieve pain in the ankle when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	 The quality of the tapping is that an unwell person should enter the bath and hurry; and tie his leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel with a long, fine bandage; for it will not appear unless for this reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	 When it appears, then tap the vein in whatever way your ability allows, either across or at an angle; and it is better to cut into it with a cut or to sever it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	 The location [of it] is healthy, and it is very much hidden in many men.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	 If you do not find [it] and it does not appear to the senses at all: then prick some branch of it, and there is one that appears on the back of the foot, turned towards the ear; and beware of nerves, and let a quantity of blood flow as much as you want.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	 Then loosen the ligature, and place the skin over the pricking site, and tighten the spot.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	 Indeed, it heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	 [Section on] Venesection, and the quality of its use.
Caput XCVIII.	 Chapter XCVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	 [They are made from] Corners, and copper, and glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	 And venesection is done according to two modes.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	 With scarification and the drawing of blood; and the other is venesection without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	 And this [form of] venesection that is without scarification, is according to two modes.
Aut enim est cum igne.	 Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	 Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	 And the places for venesection with scarification and drawing of blood on the body are fourteen.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	 One of them is the venesection of Alnocrates, and it is at the end of the head; and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; and the venesections of Alhagdahim, and they are two blades of the neck from both sides simultaneously; and the venesection of the brain, and it is under the lower jaw; and the venesections of two spoons; and the venesection of Alachosos above the end of the tail; and the venesections of two kidneys, and they are in the middle of the arms; and the venesections of the legs; and the venesections of the ankles.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	 And venesection does not extract blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and because of this its power is not drawn out from them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	 It is not necessary to administer ventosation (ventosection) with or without fire, until the entire body has evacuated, in any ailment caused by retention.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	 If necessity requires ventosation due to an ailment or custom, we administer it at the beginning, end, and middle of each month, as well as at any time it may be required.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	 That is, because from some people there arises an excess of blood, until it requires extraction through ventosation, a pain and headache are found in the head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	 And among them is one who finds retention and redness on his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	 And among them is one who finds itchiness on his face and forehead, as well as darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	 And among them is one who scratches the site of his ventosation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	 And among them is one whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	 And among them is one who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or the tongue protrudes and spits out the blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	 And among them is one whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	 And among them is one who sees in his sleep blood and redness, as well as the dead, wounds, and similar things.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	 When we therefore see something from among these, especially if it is in the middle of the third month: we then prescribe ventosation to be done, after two or three hours have passed since that day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	 The benefit of ventosation for the neck is that it relieves pressure in the head and that which is drained goes to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	 However, it must be done after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	 And this ventosation is in place of cephalic phlebotomy (venesection).
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	 It is not allowed to use it who is of a cold temperament, or where there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	 It causes him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	 Therefore, it is not appropriate for the elderly to use it, and where there are cold diseases of the head.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	 He who becomes constant over it generates forgetfulness in him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	 Therefore, you must instruct the ventilator to lower his hand with the wind for a short while towards the bottom, fearing the production of forgetfulness.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	 Ventilation or Alkehel is in place of phlebotomy for Fuscus, and phlebotomy for Basilica, and therefore it produces coughing, constriction of breath, shortness of breath due to the instrument, coughing, and filling (of the body).
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	 It must be forced to ventilate Alkehel briefly, because if it is placed below, it generates weakness in the heart and the stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	 But ventilation of alhagdahim causes accidents of pain in the head, migraines, and hemigranes (half-headaches), perforation (of a body part), and pain in the roots of the teeth: it is in place of phlebotomy for Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Therefore, you must instruct the ventilator not to press his hand during scarification, so as not to cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	 But ventilation under the chin causes alcohol in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar conditions which are in the mouth, and takes the place of phlebotomy elsewhere which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	 But ventilation with spatulas causes a condition called alchafacham, which comes from compression and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	 But ventilation of the internal parts of the two fists causes help for phlebotomy of the veins of three (types), Basilica, Fuscus and Cephalicus: because it draws blood from all those small veins which are in the flesh; and these small veins draw blood from other larger ones until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	 It is necessary that you advise the Scarifier not to proceed too much in scarifying: because the place is bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	 The one who is ventosed on the anus, relieves hemorrhoids of the anus, and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	 It is necessary that you advise the one who performs ventosing, that the ventose should be large and made of air: because the place needs strong suction, and perhaps delicate ventoses may break; and it shall be scarified by a deep scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	 Ventoses of the legs decrease with a clear reduction: because they draw blood from the whole body, and bring about old pains in the kidneys, and uterus, and bladder: they provoke menstruation, and bring forth water retention and abdominal dropsy: and they stand where phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	 Nevertheless, they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	 The help of the ventose used in alhorcobeni is close to the help of the ventoses of the two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	 The quality of the positioning of the ventose is that you place the ventose first in a void area, and apply suction moderately: and do not prolong the positioning of the ventose, but place them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place equally: and do not cease from repeating this and continuing until you see the place redden and swell, and redness of blood appears: then scarify, and perform suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	 Then consider in positioning of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	 For one who is among humans of tender flesh and few pores, it is necessary to scarify him once, not more: so that the place does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	 And command the Wind-Letter (Ventosatori) to enlarge the incision and shallow it slightly; and temper the suction in ease, speed, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	 If there is thickening in the blood, then it is necessary to incise it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	 In the first instance, an opening is made for subtle blood flow and its moisture; in the second instance, during the careful examination of deep blood extraction, thick blood is extracted.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	 If indeed the blood is extremely fetid, then an incision should be made for the third time, following it to the end.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	 And finally, when we wish to extract blood slowly or a little at a time, one incision is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	 If we wish to extract much blood, then we should make multiple incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	 And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to make a deep incision; and the end of the incision is equal to its depth.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	 \*\*What is that which should be administered from oils in the position of Wind-Letter, and what should be cautious in wind-dressing.\*\*
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	 In the case where the skin is thick, hard, dark, and the pores are tight, it is necessary to anoint the wind-letter areas with open, lenitive, and resolvent oils; if it is during summertime, as is alkali oil, or oil of wormwood, or sweet almond oil, or oil from the seed of a squash.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	 And if it is during wintertime, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or vinegar are used; and similar to these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	 If there is excessive thickening and coldness, then bitter almond oil, or balm oil, or white oil, or anise oil are used; and similar to these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	 If a wind-disease is widespread in large pores, of tender flesh: then it is necessary that oil be prohibited, and it is necessary that they clean the places of the wind after the wind-disease treatment with rose water, or with cold water, or with sea water, or with cucumber water, or with purslane water: and similar to these.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	 For the one whose blood is much moisture, clean wind-diseased places with vinegar, or with water of myrtle, and sumac: and similar to these.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	 For the one who has excessive thick ones, clean wind-diseased places with old wine, or with juniper water, or with dill boil, or chamomile: and similar to these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	 And it is necessary to avoid wind-disease treatment in a bath or near a bath, rather it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	 And it is not necessary that anyone sleeps after wind-disease treatment.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	 § What is it that is necessary to control Wind-disease or Phlebotomata before wind-disease treatment.
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	 And after that, it is necessary to consider first: then if the one who has wind-disease or phlebotomata is choleric and its sharpness and inflammation prevails over his blood: then it is necessary for him to receive cooling agents, such as grapes in honey; also oil of endive with vinegar and lettuce, and boiled leek and yolk; and similar to these.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	 And place his food as pullets, cooked mutton meat, and foods stored with vinegar: and similar to these.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	 And for the one whose complexion is cold, it is necessary to drink syrup from honey or almug or boiled leek seed: and drink moderately fragrant wine that is between old and new; and it is ordered to use sparingly food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	 Place his food with young birds, and let them warm it: and small birds, that is to say, little birds: and the young of doves shall be warmed.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	 It is necessary that on the day of ventositation and phlebotomy there be more drink than food: it is necessary to give in drink some people during Tyrian hours, or medicine made from musk, that is, muscatel, or alesselith before ventosation; and before or after phlebotomy, so that the main limbs are strengthened, and the blood becomes thin.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	 It is not necessary to drink it in hot liquids.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	 Chapter on ventositation without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	 Ventosations that are without scarification are those placed on the liver, spleen, podagra, stomach, navel, places of kidneys, and the ankle pit: because these members do not allow scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	 Nor does it seek through these, except the attraction of blood from one member to another; as we place ventosation on the breasts in the sickness of nasal bleeding.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	 We make use of them to remove cold and offensive ventositation from one member by another; as we place ventosation on the stomach, and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	 For it rarefies the member, heats it up, and removes pain for that reason, because it has resolved that ventositation.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	 Also placed over the kidneys when there is pus or stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	 For by its virtue, perhaps it opens up pus, or removes the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	 And similarly when placed over the liver and spleen for the purpose of bleeding in both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	 These ventosations are administered empty with incision only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	 And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	 And sometimes they are administered with warm water in the afflictions of pleurisy: and this is to be filled with a Ventose, and it should be large, hot water alone, or water in which herbs that agree have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	 Form of the ventose administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	 Let the width of its opening be two fingers wide, as we have formed it; and let its depth be half a palm; and let there be on its side, in a place about halfway along it, a small hole, according to the size that the needle can enter; make it from brass or citron wood, with the edges rounded, equal, and smoothed; so as not to hurt the limb when placed upon it; and let there be in the middle of it a crossbar transverse from brass or iron, where the candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	 And now this ventose is made large, larger than we have said, but not much smaller than it, according to the afflictions and age of the one who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	 For the ventoses of boys and those wasted are other than the ventoses of men and those with large bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	 The quality of placing this ventose with fire upon a limb is to light a linen cloth with fire properly, or a small candle from tallow; and place it on the middle crossbar that is in the middle of the ventose; so that the fire may be lit about half-way down the ventose, so as not to burn the body of the sick person.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	 Then it is placed upon a limb; and the finger should be on the hole that I said, until we hold the ventose; while we need it, let us remove the finger, and steam will come out through the hole, and the ventose will immediately break.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	 Then, linen cloth according to its kind, and heat it if necessary.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	 In pneumothorax that is administered in the case of pleurisy with water, there is no bladder or hole; it is not administered except because it is filled with water and placed only on the member.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	 And this pneumothorax, as it is larger, to take in more water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	 \ paragraph on Suspension of Sugar of Lead.
Caput XCIX.	 Chapter XCIX.
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	 Sanguisugae are not administered in many cases, unless in those members where the position of the ventous sacs is not possible due to their small size, such as lips, gums, and similar places.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	 Or in the naked member devoid of flesh, such as fingers, nose, and similar places.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	 And the quality of using them is that you come from the Sanguisuga which are in sweet, clean waters free of decay.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	 Then they should be placed day and night in sweet water until they are hungry, and nothing remains in their belly.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	 Then the body is bled first with phlebotomy, and with ventosus.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	 Then cleanse the sick member until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	 Then they are placed upon it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	 When they are filled and fall, and there is a possibility of squeezing the place with the ventous sac, then it is more helpful for relief; and if not, then cleanse the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	 Then with much water, rub and squeeze.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	 If the course of the blood is prolonged after the removal of the Sanguisuga and it persists, then soak a piece of linen cloth in cold water and place it on top until the perspiration disappears.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If blood is multiplied, then on it powderize zeugite crushed or gall-like substances from styptics, until the blood is cut off.
