Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or powders made from halved and peeled beans may be placed on the location, and left until the beans stick to the spot, for the blood is cut off.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And if it is necessary to repeat the application of Sanguisugars, when possible, they should be changed.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 But if Sanguisugars are forbidden from suspension, then the location should be cleaned with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or insert a lancet into the locations until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then they are placed, for when they feel something from the blood, they will stick immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 When you wish for them to fall, powderize something from crushed aloes, or salt, or ashes on them; and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	¶ End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	¶ Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Third Part.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 § Universal Discourse on Restoring, Dislocating, and Treating Twisting and Similar Conditions.
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is also frequently necessary in the art of medicine, and it is the restoration of fractures and dislocations of bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.	 Know ye, O sons, that foolish physicians and the common people boast about this chapter, and those who have never examined an ancient book nor read a letter from it.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And for this reason, the method is deprived of knowledgeable people in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never encountered this method in any good way, and I was not proficient in it unless through the length of reading ancient books and my interest in understanding them, until I extracted knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I affix with experiment and study to the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 I have now described for you all that contains my knowledge from that chapter, and whatever exceeded my experience, since I abbreviated it for you, and freed it from the occupation of elongation, and abbreviated it to the end of abbreviation, and displayed it at the end of decline; and I have formed many shapes in it from the shapes of instruments used in it, as I did in the two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 The total and the collections from the fractures of bones, from those whose removal is necessary before we begin to recall the members broken and diverse, if any one of them.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary to say at the beginning of this chapter the sum of speech and the headings, to which understanding is first required for the craftsman to his station regarding their truth; namely that you and those who are quick may know or learn this noble art from you, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say therefore that when fracture, dislocation, twist or fall occurs to someone, then it is necessary that you quickly go to him for bloodletting and resolving, or both at once; if not prohibited by something like weakness of strength; or he to whom this happens is a child, or old and decrepit; or the time is very hot or very cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, beans and heads; and prohibit wine, thick meats, and filling of foods and every food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until you are secure from a hot fever and do not fear effusion of matter to the limb; then let the weak return to his own regimen first, with which his accustomed practice was.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the broken bone begins to heal, then it is necessary that the sick person be fed with nourishing food in abundance, thick, heavy, in which there is viscosity; such as food made from cooked wheat with water, rice, and heads, feet, and entrails of cattle, eggs, and fresh fish; also thick wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 With this regimen, the healing of the fracture occurs more quickly, and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that the bones fractured in men who are in the first old age and worn out, it is not possible for them to be joined together and healed according to their nature always, because of the drying up of their limbs; they are consolidated and joined together which come from those at the end of softness, like the bones of small boys.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to glue around the broken bone from all sides, which has thickness, so that it adheres and tightens it until they are consolidated on both sides, until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was in the beginning, until it does not prohibit anything from its operations; and for this reason it is necessary to put nourishment for the sick man, which has thickness, viscosity, and heaviness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the diversity of limbs; since a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head of the bone; and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the backbone; and similarly all other limbs exist differently from one another; and I come with the reminder of every type of fracture exposed in its own chapter distinguished from others.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of bone fracture are diversified even within themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since the fracture of it is arched, furthermore stars occur in it. (Stars here refer to protrusions or irregularities in the broken bone.)
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes the fracture of it occurs along the length of the bone; and there are fractures called star-shaped, that is, stars, and additions proceeding, as in a reed when it is cut with a knife to write. (Here, the analogy suggests that the fractured bone has protrusions like the fibers in a reed when it's cut.)
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not proceeding; and there is a fracture with a wound and splitting at the head; and there is a small split fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every species has a skill or proper tool for its restoration according to its recollection, which is distinguished in its respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which the bone fracture is known, there is its crookedness, and its elevation; and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when you compress it with your hand. (Here, the description implies that a fractured bone may have an irregular shape, elevated edges, be visible or palpable, and produce a sound upon compression.)
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore there is no apparent crookedness in its location, nor a sound when you touch the bone with movement, nor does it find a weak great pain; then there is no fracture there, indeed it may be that it is a crookedness or a small split; therefore, you should not move it with your hand and compression altogether, instead place it on top of some medicine whose recollection comes to mind, after the appropriate time; then it is tied down gently. (Here, the advice suggests that if there's no apparent crookedness, sound upon touch or strong pain in a particular area, then it may not be a fracture. In such cases, the bone should be left undisturbed and treated with suitable medicine.)
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that when a place arches and splits into two, furthermore stars occur in it, yet all parts are removed from their comparison; then it is necessary for you to begin at your hour for its correction, aligning it before an abscess of hot pus occurs on it. (This passage suggests that if a fracture splits into two and shows star-shaped protrusions, all the parts should be aligned for correction to prevent an abscess of hot pus from forming.)
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If however a boil occurs warm, then let it be left for some days until the boil subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then equal it accordingly to whatever method is possible by gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration of it, and its equalization, is easier than a bone, in which fractures occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then bind it, according to when you will remember it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If however there are fractures in the bone, then it is necessary to extend this broken member from both parts, if it is a hand or foot: or with your hand, if the part is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 Let your position be such that you place the member on a level surface according to its natural shape, until when the parts of the broken member are extended: then try, by any means possible, to make those additions return, and in their places: and be careful according to your strength, lest pain or injury occurs due to your operation. And try according to your strength, to apply one of two bones with its companion, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 It is necessary at that hour that you test and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see something abnormal there, correct it and equal it out according to the quantity of your power.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And beware of excessive extension and strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For often they cause boils to occur by their operation, or contraction in a limb: as we have already seen this many times from their operations.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then connect after the equalization and proper operation, and tightening of that limb, and peace, and calmness: and warn the weak against it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 Make him take care that he does not move himself during the hours of his vigil, and during the revolutions of his sleep, and during his agitation, and during his digestion, and all his movements with utmost strength.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 Make him take care that there is no position of the limb which follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 This is because when he feels pain or injury in the position of a limb, then it is necessary to change him to another position from which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And be careful that his position is equal and straight; so that there is no twisting in the limb when it is restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 The quality of the binding of a broken limb is as I have told.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that broken limbs are classified according to their smallness, size, and shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those which are small, such as the arm, the finger, the wrist and similar ones, then it is necessary that there be a soft, fine wrapping of cloth around them.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 Those which are large, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary that there be a wide, hard wrapping around them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a broad binding connects a large limb and binds it from all sides with an equal pressure so that no spot is left uncovered.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then after your evacuation, begin to place the appropriate ointment on it on a soft woolen cloth over the site of the fracture.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wrap the binding over the site of the fracture three or four times, according to how deserving the limb is; and tighten your hand slightly with the binding.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go with him to the upper part above the site of the fracture and tighten it less than your previous binding which you had bound the broken place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then stretch yourself slightly with a gentle pulling away from the location of the fracture, and gradually soften the stiffness, until you can grasp a large amount from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another poultice and apply it again over the fractured location with more layers.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Afterwards, go down with the poultice to the lower part below the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your work be in the stiffness of the poultice and its softening, according to what was said in the first layer of poultice application.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place soft materials such as wool or cloth between the poultice layers to match the curvature of the fracture, if there is a curvature; and if not, do not put anything in that area.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then apply another layer of poultice over it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place evenly arranged stars (small elevations) immediately on top of these poultice layers if there is no swelling or warm abscess in that area.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 But if there is swelling or an abscess there: then place on it what sits the abscess and remove the swelling; and leave it for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then bind tightly the evenly arranged stars (small elevations).
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 Let the small elevations be made from pieces of wide reeds that have been shaved and shaped wisely; or let them be made of wood from which cribra (cobble-stones) are made, such as pine or yew, or calingi (small wooden balls); and let the width of each elevation be in this shape and this same form.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, the elevation that is placed on the fracture should be slightly larger and wider than the others; and the length of the elevation should be according to what is allowed by the size and smallness of the limb.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind tightly over the elevations with another layer of poultice, according to the first binding.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind above with threads properly, as we have said concerning the stricture: and it is that your stricture be over the place of the fracture more: and as it is more elongated from the fracture, the stricture is smaller.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 It is necessary that the threads be of medium thickness and fineness, and they should be of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 Since if the threads are thick, as I have seen from the operation of foolish people putting their threads made from twisted cords of rough linen, it is a great mistake: because the stricture falls with them beyond its quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And again, fine threads do not suit: since you will not achieve with the stricture what you desire with them.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 And it is not necessary that there be less than a finger between one astel and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If a sick person is injured by the extremities of the astels after the stricture in healthy places: then place under them from soft wool or camel's hair wool until nothing is injured from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 But when there is a fracture with a wound, and it happens that the disruption occurs in the skin, I will come again with its reminder in the second chapter regarding its uniqueness.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every fractured limb needs to be bound with astels from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 Because a limb that is large should not have upper astels placed on it unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the onset of the hot swelling.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 This is the method of plasters, which the ancients used, that are placed over a fracture and dislocation.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 § Common emplaster method abbreviated, restoring the fracture, suitable for various temperaments, especially women and children: since it is from that which heat does not conquer nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is to receive from the flour mill dust and it is the marrow of the flour that hangs on the walls of the mill next to the millstone movement; and make it as it is, except that you sieve it with egg white: and place its preparation not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method for emplaster is for healing a fracture, and dislocation, and a twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Make almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath: and macerate all of them in ten parts of myrrh, and five parts each of aloes, and twenty parts of alethil: grind all of them and sift, and mix with water of alethil; or with cow's milk, if the bandage of the sick person is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this emplaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is of good composition, heals quickly broken bones and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method for emplaster also benefits a fracture and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Make mugath, mess, white alteae, all of them in ten parts of myrrh, and five parts each of aloes, and six parts of acacia, twenty parts of Armenian pounded bolus: grind all of them with much grinding, sift, and make with water or cow's milk: and administer.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method for emplaster for joining together, and separated bones from their places: and eases the pain that happens to them, and splitting of the bone, and fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take boiled wool, immerse it in vinegar and boiled oil: and place it on the spot.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And indeed, there is no virtue of healing in this emplaster, but it is good for the soothing of a hot abscess: and it expels pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Another method for emplaster that heals a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take leaves of the deaf fig tree and wild papaver leaves: grind all of them, and make an emplaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Another short method for emplaster, administered for healing a broken bone: and when you wish the dissolution of a remaining abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Prepare a root of althea (Marshmallow), chamomile, flowers of violets, and a portion of the herb flour - all in equal parts: grind them all and make a paste with wine, unless the member is heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated, then make paste with water of coriander (Coriander) seeds or with water, and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger plaster method for resolving a hard fistula when restoring a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Prepare a root of althea (Marshmallow), flax seeds, boxwood, lentil, henna, wormwood, flowers of violets, and chamomile - all in equal parts: grind them all and make a paste with water of willow, or sweet water, or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply the whole thing according to the member's warmth and the calmness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates, however, did not say in his book that it should be placed on a fractured member during its restoration, unless it is made of pitch and oil; nothing else; he said it should be of medium thickness between coarseness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus, however, thought that these substances with the extraction of heat should be placed on a fractured member during its restoration, such as myrrh, aloes, frankincense, and similar things from what we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Another plaster method that heals injuries and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Prepare milled (or very finely ground) figs, chickpeas, hair of man or feathers of bird, althea (Marshmallow), and salt - all in equal parts: grind them, sift them, and make a paste; then make a plaster from it.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The quantity of the bandage that should remain according to which it is necessary, then it is loosened, should be considered when there is no weak pain, itching, or moving of the fractured bone from its place; then do not loosen it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If it happens to him at a place itching strongly, or distressing pain, or swelling: then hurry and dissolve (the plaster) in an hour of that (affected part), and remove the plaster from him: and take soft cloth or sea sponge, moist: and immerse it in warm water, and clean the place with it until the itching subsides, and the pain is relieved.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then allow the member to rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place over it soft wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil: and bind over it at night until you are secure from hot inflammation, and the swelling of the member subsides, and the pain is relieved.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeatedly apply to it a narrow bandage and small plaster: and do not bind (it) with your first constriction and fine ones until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all the other symptoms have been completely removed: and you require plaster and bandage, then repeat this as you did in the first place equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of what we said happens to the member: then do not dissolve (the plaster) before three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is released for 20 days according to what appears to you from the dissolution of the member, as we said, until when a fracture adheres and coagulation of flesh on it: add also in the bandage more than your first bandage completely: and add also in the thickening of food according to what was mentioned before its recall.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see the place of the fracture already dry out and become thinner than necessary: then know that nutrition is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Dissolve it (the embrocation) with warm water at every place where you apply it, and let it be in all three days, and it will slightly relieve the stricture.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 Through this procedure, nourishment flows to the member, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 What the foolish restorers do in place of a fractured member, when it is not restored as required, and they restore it according to its curvature, is an error due to their procedure, and there is great fear: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said so in their books, and they would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have never seen any trace of theirs in this at all, and it is better that it not be done.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 Chapter on the making of an incision in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 Types of fractures are diverse, and their shapes are many; and their causes are distinct.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For from a fracture is one that occurs by striking with a sword; and the strike removes bone completely up to the point where it reaches the siphac (a ligament beneath the skull), just as an ax does in wood, and for this reason this type of fracture is called "Axial".
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the sword strikes some bone and cuts its surface but does not penetrate through the incision to the end; and this type of fracture is called "Kalan", that is, an Absolute Lever.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And a wound can be either of two types of fractures, large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from a fracture is one that is a crushing or rubbing; and its cause is a blow with a stone, a fall onto a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also one that penetrates, which is close to the panniculus (a layer beneath the skull), or it is on the surface of the bone; and this wound can be either of two types of fractures, large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from a fracture is one which is hidden within the bone at the subtlety of the hair; and it is a small crack, and for this reason this type of fracture is called capillary fracture.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And there is a fracture which occurs by accident or striking with a stone, and similar things that cause a layer of the bone to enter within, making a hollow place; as happens to anvils when struck, and part of them enters within.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 Indeed it happens most often in the wet bones of skulls, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And there are all these kinds of separating fractures, and I will mention them with the whole thing in its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 We recognize all these kinds of fractures by examination on it and investigation of them with probing tools, and removal of corrupted flesh that is upon them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The capillary type is recognized by this, that it appears on the bone and is scraped off, and it is limited with an encaustic iron; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of fractures, consider first the condition of the patient; if you see signs from his condition that are clearly indicative of fear, such as vomiting choler, extension, loss of intellect, loss of voice, fainting, acute fever, discharge of the eyes, redness of them, and similar things among various conditions, it will probably not heal; and if you see signs that do not frighten you, and hope for recovery; then begin the treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If a wounded man comes to you first with his wound; and this is during the days of winter, then it is necessary that you strive in bone removal before the 14th day according to all conditions.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 If it is in the days of summer, then it is necessary that you hasten to remove the bone before the seventh day, before it corrupts what is under the bone from the fat, and such accidents as I have mentioned occur.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of a bone has already reached the fat touching the brain and it is accompanied by small pieces and traction, then it is necessary that you cut the fragmented and smoothed part, as I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is necessary to shave the head of the wounded and to dig into the bone according to whatever method is possible for you, and according to the shape of the wound and what is light on what is weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If while digging into the bone there occurs a flow of blood or a hot abscess, then apply what is necessary to it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is necessary to fill the place with soaked rags in wine and rose oil, and let the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be secure from bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin in the healing of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 The first method is to cut the bone with a sharp chisel: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another chisel wider than the previous one: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then administer yet another chisel even wider than the second.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is to have a number of chisels of different sizes among you, some wider than others, and some shorter than others: and they should be at the end of sharpness, and made of iron or steel, and use them with ease when striking the chisel so as not to strike the head and injure it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard and firm, then it is necessary that you bore around its circumference before you administer Incisoria, with Terebris which are named Terebra not penetrating too deep: and they are not called so unless because themselves do not pass beyond the bone's meaty limit to what is beyond it; therefore, because the Terebrum has a rounded extremity above that which is under its head and is sharp, similar to an edge, and a small circle prevents immersion, and passing through the bone's thickness.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 It is necessary for you to take a large number of Terebris from these, each one of which should correspond to the thickness of the bone, until you have all the Terebrum for that bone: whose sharp extremity's length and width should be in accordance with the thickness of that bone.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the shape of three kinds of Terebrums or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of boring around the bone's circumference when it is broken, is: that you place the Terebrum on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the Terebrum to another place and put what is between every hole of that quantity or approximately.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with Incisoria what is between every hole of the bone: and make it as fine as possible on its edge, as we have said, until you remove the bone, either with your hand or with certain instruments which you have prepared for that purpose, such as tenaliae and delicate forceps.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary to avoid all caution so that the Terebrum or Incisoria does not touch any part of the siphac.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you are boring around the bone and it is separated from the siphac, if it is continuous with it and you extract it, then it is necessary that you grind and level its remaining extremity in the bone with another similar instrument like an Incisoria.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 It is necessary that it [the instrument] be thin and delicate more than other incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains from the small bones and cartilage: then take it with ease, with that which is at hand from your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound after that with linen cloths and ointments as we said before.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 And another method of operation is easy and entirely far from fear; which Galen said and praised greatly; and this is his saying.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 It is necessary for you first to begin to expose the bone part from the place where the fracture is more violent and more apparent; until when you have exposed that part and placed under it the extreme end of this convex incisor, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 And the convex part, the convex does not cut anything; and the sharp part of it in its two sides going in length as you see: so that the convex part is attached to the ulna, with the sharp part incident on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike upon the convexor with a small hammer until you incise the whole bone with ease, as it is revolved; and be careful that no cloth slips into what happens to slip which you fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician were not more foolish than men, and less ignorant of his craft, nor sleeping, then if something remained attached to the bone from a cloth in some places, he would cut it off with the extreme end of the convex incisor and free it with ease.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the fracture of the bone does not penetrate to the cloth and what is cut off from the bone is the face of it, and roughness and delicate cartilage remain in it: then it is necessary that you smooth down the roughness, and remove the delicate cartilage with subtle rasps which you have prepared in various quantities, so that it is possible for you to apply them more conveniently and correctly in every place according to what leads you the operation, and the fractured bone, and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And it is necessary that you administer, according to your own judgment, first of all cutting the bone, more widely with those larger saws.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer one after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease doing it continuously until you reach the point of administering thinner and finer [things], and subtler than all those [other things].
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each of the remaining small cracks and subtle fractures, it is necessary to administer care, according to that which leads to the correction of [them].
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a matter which is not hidden over all, to whichever pursuit this art has been devoted, and it stands upon that which we have written and shown concerning large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If, however, a piece of cloth is detected and retained when you are removing the bone: then it is necessary that you take linen cloth according to the size of the wound, and dip it into rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another double or triple piece of cloth, and dip it into wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth: and do this as easily as possible above it, so that it is not heavy.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer over it a broad bandage: and do not tighten it unless by the amount which holds the wound only: and release it with this care for one day or two days, until you are secure from hot infection.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it and administer afterwards medicines with which excess dryness is needed: such as the roots of the garlic, and the flour of herbs, and sandalwood powder, and aristolochia, and similar [substances]: and there is that you make from these medicines a powder, which is to be sprinkled over the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer all medicine for the property of which it is for cleansing and not biting.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 Avoid, according to your skill, that the wound during your treatment is clean: neither be there in it dirt from ointment, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Do not allow pus to collect at all on it because when pus accumulates on a cerebral padding, it corrupts it and makes it rot, and after that it brings about great harm for the sick person: and already it has happened on the skull-bone, when the bone is being cleaned by him, especially when the care of it is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Then if the accidents that I have mentioned happen to the sick person, know that it is certainly dangerous.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 And if blackness does not appear except from the medicine that is applied to it and the medicine has this property to make it black: then you must take one part of honey and three parts of rose oil, and anoint it with these.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place it on the skull-bone: afterwards take care of it with suitable means of healing until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 Restoration of the nose when it is broken.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except for two of its upper parts at once, or one of them: because there are two bones in it; since below it is cartilaginous, it does not break and it does not happen to it unless there is rubbing, and twisting, and curvature.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of its two parts is broken, then you must insert a small finger into the nostril and hold the broken part with your index finger and thumb on the outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; this should be done skillfully with ease.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And take care that pain does not happen to the sick person during your treatment.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose, and it does not reach that with the finger: then it is necessary that the end of the radius should be equalized, where there is a small swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture occurs in two parts, then make it similar to that one: and approach with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if it is possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day at a place of warm fumigation.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of linen from a linen cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two pieces of linen if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be a swelling of such size in the linen that it fills the nostril opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the old restorers said to immerse the linen pieces in butter and change them every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But I do not see this, rather it is necessary that the linen piece should be immersed in egg white, prepared with miller's flour.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then release the linen, until the bone hardens and the cartilage thickens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the nose where the linen was, after soft cloth has been placed on top of it; and this holds the nasal fracture more strongly, so that a sick person may not be prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you wish, do it; and if you wish, do with the linen pieces.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose happens to develop a wound while operating on a warm fumigation, apply nasal plasters with tar, or with pitch softened in rose oil, or a little bit of alkali.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if no warm fumigation occurs, then it is necessary that the plasters be applied with camel's flour and incense powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft cloth upon him (the patient), and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If the bones of the nose are broken and fractured in a small way or crushed, then it is necessary that you cut open and extract them with suitable instruments.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then suture it (the wound), and take care of him with whatever that promotes healing, and consolidates it from suitable ointments or plasters for that purpose.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If there is a wound in the nose, then it is necessary that you take care of him with linen cloths: and administer a leaden cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on Restoring the Lower Jaw when it is broken.
Caput V.	 Head V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is broken and there is no wound associated with it, then examine whether its breakage is only on the outside and it is not fractured into two and curves towards the inside: in such a case, its diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the breakage is on the right side, insert your left index finger into the patient's jaw: similarly, if the breakage is in the left jaw, then insert your right index finger: and push with it the curvature of the fracture towards the outside with ease using your other hand from the inner part of the bone correctly, and with equal force on the same side.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the broken jaw is already separated into two parts, then it is necessary to administer an extension from both sides according to straightness: until it is possible for them to be aligned equally.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If there has already been movement or disruption of the teeth, then tie together those that you hope will remain with a gold wire, silver wire, or silk thread.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place a soft cloth over the broken jaw (mandible).
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place on top of him a double cloth, and place upon the cloth a well-made large pin or an equal piece of shoelather along the length of the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind him above as you prepare his bandage and its application suits him until it does not break down; and instruct the sick one to rest peacefully and quietly; and place soft food for his loosening diet.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you find that something has changed in his shape in any way: then hasten and cut him open on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then correct what has been distorted from it, and plaster him with flour of mill, with egg white or wheat flour after you have removed the purulent matter; and place a soft woolen cloth on top of the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While the aforementioned plaster remains on him and the bone arrangement does not change, leave him as he is, without cutting, until he is healed; or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 For this fracture is often bound for three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If a hot abscess occurs in the meantime, then administer what I said many times for its reduction until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if there is a fracture with a wound, consider.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If the fractured part is separated from the bone or cartilage: then be subtle in this matter, so that you remove those fragments of cartilage with what suits you in their removal using tools.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the wound opening is narrow: then widen it with a leech according to the quantity required by you.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the cartilage and there is nothing left of it, or if the wound opening is wide: and if it is not, place on top of it an appropriate plaster and let it heal until healed.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 On the restoration of a fractured crossbar (Furcula).
Caput VI.	 Title VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The crossbar (Furcula) is most frequently broken from the front part near the humerus, and its fracture occurs in one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Or it is broken into two pieces beyond which there occur protrusions; and this is easier for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Or thus, when the protrusion occurs in the bone itself; and this is more difficult for its restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or it is broken with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the operation in this case, when there is no wound, consists of making two assistants present; one to hold firmly the broken crossbar, and the other to stretch out the neck towards the side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then equalize the fracture with your fingers until its form is achieved as required; and there should be no prominence or concavity in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you need more extension, then it is necessary to place under the patient's chin a sphere made of cloth or wool; and its size should be according to the quantity of your need; stretch and elevate the crossbar, and press the sphere with your hand until you equalize the fracture as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the extremity of the crossbar to the outside because it has reached deep; then the patient should lie on his back on his neck; and place a block under his shoulder in size, and press the assistant's arm towards the bottom until the bone of the crossbar is elevated from the deep to the top; at that point, correct the fracture and equalize it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 But if you feel a protrusion from the crossbar and it moves; then it is necessary to press down on it and extract the protrusion easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If it is retained in the bone, then use instruments prepared for incision of that kind, after you place under a lever the instrument which serves as a grip; and the instrument is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail shell without a concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to what you need for it due to the size of the bone and its part.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 But its length should also be as possible for you in surgery.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And it shall have two ends, as you see: one end shall be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If the fracture of the wound that you have cut when removing the splinter of bone is wide, and it is hot, then gather together two lips of the wound with stitching.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the fracture is small or you fear a hot abscess, then fill the wound with cloths and wool according to the size of the cut in the wound.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 And if it happens that a hot abscess occurs, then pour cloth in rose oil, vinegar, and wine on it, and place it over it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But the setting of bone without a wound and without an incision is, to place plaster on it made from flour milled with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And put soft wool over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere under its edge if needed.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take the rotula (bloodletter), that is, a rod held by Arabs, which should be very long; and its width should be about one palm or nearly that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place doubled wool over the soft wool and the plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take an awl made of thin wood, whose width should be three fingers, and the same in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then roll her (it) in a cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then roll the bandage with starch in the place of alumen that falls over the fracture and the wound.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place alumen on the fracture as it is rolled, and roll it over its neck, and under the healthy titillicum and the weak one: and bring it back over all parts, so that you can see that the ligature holds the fracture tightly: and this is what should not be covered by you, and completely, so that the starch does not remove the splint from the fractured bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 And for this reason, it is necessary to examine the weak one every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 How often then does the bandage become soft and you see the starch already removed? Then correct it, and tighten the bandage.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the pillow of the sick one on his back, and put a small cushion under the healthy titillicum for him at night, so that with it he lifts up the assistance from the side himself.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Then lift the fracture of the collarbone through lifting the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind the arm to the neck of the same; and do not loosen the bandage, unless it happens in the place that occurs from itching or sores, until twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add to the ligature and release it, until it heals and hardens.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The fracture of the collarbone is tightened and strengthened to a great extent for twenty days; and sometimes it happens in fewer in some men.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the healing of the fracture of the spatula.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 Rarely does the spatula break and in a wide place of it; and they do not break from it except for its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When a place is broken from it and breaks in the middle of it, and it can only be known through touch: then prepare for the fracture according to its figure.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 Reduce it to its natural form by all means possible of your intellect.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place on the place powder from a mill with albumen of egg, and soft wax, and put on top a small piece of double-fold cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place over it a broad awl from thin wood according to the size of the spatula or slightly larger.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If there is any concavity under the awl in the spatula, then equal the concavity with soft wax until the awl descends according to equality.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then bind above it with long alum strips, with a suitable tightening, and the awl's firmness, until it is not moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 Consider the binding every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the binding becomes soft, bind it again, and equal the awl if it is moved from its place: let it lie weak on the healthy side.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 The spatula should be restored in twenty or thirty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number has been completed, then loosen the binding: and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is from the bones whose fracture is not feared nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If it proceeds from a bone splinter and pierces below the skin: then cut through it, and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we said for a fracture of the neck of the scapula by hot cautery, if something happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of breast fractures.
